review_text:
An update broke the AI for a lot of factions, making them passive. This include TK and lizardmen, but not only (ogre spamming camp near one settlement and doing nothing too).

This allow other faction near it to expand more than intended, fully breaking the early, mid and end game balance depending on your starting position.

I suggest not buying solely because of this, and might change my review if they fix it in a timely manner (it's already been months, so it's looking quite bad, they clearly don't care and didn't bother testing because it's extremely obvious).

review_text:
It runs like garbage. 


But it is super fun. 

The devs keep giving free content and changing previous paid content to be cheaper or easier to get, some having become free. 
You can also preview the paid for content in game to an extent.
I have almost 500 hour and over 2000 hours of the previous 2 titles, warhammer 2 and are are more like expansions rather than separate games with the biggest changes being graphical fidelity. 
The game is massive even with just the base game and no dlc. 
The game and dlc goes on special regularly and on good discounts if you want the extra content but do not want to pay full price for it.
I am of at the time of writing this have spent almost 35 hours in one campaign and in base there are a potential of 7 of them, not including the tutorial which is very impressive, or the big campaign.
There is also a big variety of mods available that makes the average to ugly female characters into the more lore accurate incredibly hot and attractive with mods to change units or characters into wearing skimpy clothing if the sjw aspects (it is a British game after all) are too much for you. Which can be found on the
steam workshop (Least amount of none sjw mods)
Nexus (high amount of none sjw mods)
Loverslab (No SJW mods)
The game is fantastic without mods to begin with, they just make the viewing experience if you like to zoom in and look at your units like i do, a much more pleasant and rewarding experience. Side note i placed almost 3000 hours before installing sexy mods so it isn't as important for the enjoyment of the game but the mediocre to ugly female models do get annoying after all that time.

Overall it is a fantastic game with hundreds of hours of content, mods to fix some bad or none lore accurate aspects, and specials to make up for the high amount of dlc that the game has.
I highly recommend it.
Review_Angles: Technical Performance, Gameplay Enjoyment, Consumer Value & Content

review_text:
This game is a lot of fun, it is my first total war game ever and I have about 1200 hours on all TWWH games combined. So I have a decent amount of knowledge with the game both pros and cons.
Pros: 
1. Dwarfs, they're badass
2. Skaven (hehe funny rats)
3. Mod support is great
4. A lot of different races that all play differently and each sub-faction within those races that play different than others with campaign buffs, start positions, etc.
5. Battles are fun and engaging
6. Ever since WH3 dropped, CA has been receiving backlash and since the disaster that was Shadows of Change, CA seemed to have turned a new leaf with content. DLC can get a lil expensive but CA has been dropping a lot of free update content and they're going to continue to do so.
7. The AI is alright (at times)
Cons:
1. The AI is either alright or completely dumb. 
2. Difficulty is wonky imo. I'm the type of guy that prefers dumber AI the easier the difficulty is and vice versa. If you set it to a higher difficulty, the AI just gets stat buffs that kinda prevent certain styles of play (can't really go a melee army because of the damage buffs the AI gets)
3. Co-Op campaigning is easy to get desynced and disconnected. Idk if this has to do with my friend's connection or the game itself. One day it was working, the next day it wasn't. 
4. The game will randomly crash sometimes. Annoying to deal with but since the game autosaves after every turn it's whatever. 
5. Each TWWH game is a add-on to the previous game, so if you bought WH3 but didn't buy WH1 or WH2, you're locked out of 80% of the races until you buy those games, luckily you can get cheap copies off of Gee Two A.
6. Siege battles suck. The AI and my units can't path around properly during siege battles, and they're more of a grind than fun and engaging. 
7. Bretonnians (The French 🤢)
I recommend getting if you're into RTS games. Look for deals on Gee Two A since they're cheaper than buying it straight off of Steam.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Variety, Content Value, Developer Support

Review_Angles: Character Immersion, Narrative Engagement

review_text:
Creative Assembly has been known for making good strategy games, however they have been steadily decreasing in quality and increasing in bugs. Warhammer Fantasy is a much loved franchise, and they for the most part do a good job of realizing the world and sturggles between factions.

However the game still has many bugs that go unaddressed while they continue to price gouge the dlc for ridiculous prices. Their is no good reason for these prices besides believing that you, the end user, are a complete mook and easily parted from your money.

If they focused more on balancing the game and fixing bugs rather than holding those necessary things ransom by insisting that you must purchase the same thing at a ridiculous price then its best to no longer support them. I do not recommend purchasing this game at full price or at all, and I also do not recommend buying any dlc for this game until they decide to lower the prices to what they were in previous games, if not lower than that to make up for their continual blunders.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Developer Practices

review_text:
It pains me to make this, but at its current state I just could not recommend this game unless you are an insanely big Warhammer fan.

I feel as though the people who created the campaign were so focused on "Doesn't it sound cool if X" without thinking about how it would actually interact in the games format.  It completely goes against everything that made Total War fun to begin with.  Expanding, dominating, and growing your forces larger to take on all sorts of enemies as you conquer the map.

This isn't what happens at all in this game.  It actively punishes you for expanding by creating random chaos portals that spread corruption and armies across your entire empire while your (Likely) best army has screwed off somewhere else for the McGuffin.  3/4ths of my game is just sitting in a city and pressing the skip notification button until one of the portals opens back up to send a unit in.  If one of the other people in there just happen to get to the soul before you? Too bad, guess you gotta wait 20 turns again to try again.

And don't even get me started on these new Dominion battles.  I'm not sure who came up with the idea, but when I build an army of best units I have I want to have an epic battle with all that the enemy has to offer, not a Nascar endurance race of endless spawning enemies hitting you from behind the entire time you are advancing and from every single side endlessly basically making you "Base Race" till the end.  This may be a personal opinion, but these battles aren't fun...they are frustrating.

I have loved every Warhammer game, and many of the total war games.  They have their flaws, but also their charms.  Many of them came out with bugs and glitches (I'm looking at you Rome), but most have gotten better.  I sincerely hope that CA comes back around to fix this hot garbage of a campaign, or at least release Immortal Empires sooner rather than later.  I will gladly get rid of my negative review when it does.  Until then, I'm just going to go back to Warhammer 2 to get my fantasy fix.

Edit: As they have now updated the game with Immortal Empires I am flipping this review.  However OG campaign is still awful.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Design, Consumer Value, Franchise Alignment

review_text: The dynamics of the game are way different this time around. The first few times I played through it, i just didn't understand the goal and kept losing even though i had many armies. After a while I understood that traversing the rifts is necessary to win and finally I understood. After that, the game became much more fun to play! I will say the basics of playing are exactly the same, even down to almost the same buildings/trees. I would have loved to see something different.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Learning Curve, Content Novelty

review_text: I have played total war for years. It is great to finally get a campaign that is more interesting than paint the map. To get a "victory" in the campaign, you must send your faction leader's army to chaos realms four times. This means rapid expansion is penalized which creates a fun dynamic. I want to expand enough to support a strong 2 army team, but not so much that I can't defend it with those two armies. This is a fun challenge, and it feels right lore-wise. Cathay wouldn't paint the map usually. The demonic factions always have to worry about being stabbed in the back. That's why a chaos invasion from the north is so rare - they cant trust each other. This campaign encourages more strategic thinking, it encourages the race (unlike WH2), and it fits the lore.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Innovation, Lore Consistency, Strategic Depth

They nailed the art style and the voice actors on this one. The game has a very high quality of stand overall. You can be good or you can be evil, no matter what you chose, you will have lots of fun. Overall the game is so much fun and so much work has put into it without a doubt. 

But there is one thing I need to mention, no matter what machine you run it at, turn times on the Immortal Empires campagin are too long. I am running it on a high end pc and turn times needs a fix, been playing it since release and it never got fixed. Apart from that, game is just sooo good.

review_text:
Yet another game with constant nonsense that requires endless modding to fix the game. A lot of features are all arcade mode cringe style even though total war games have a fan base that prefer realism. During sieges you can make wooden towers on the spot which makes no sense for a castle that already has stone towers. Why not have the towers already be built as stone and have it where you need to send soldiers and ammo to towers by spending the points? 
Cavalry can break down castle gates making siege rams totally pointless. The random rebel armies that spawn out of thin air can totally ruin campaigns. Siege towers are very easy to destroy by shooting at them and then the entire unit in the tower dies making it actually pointless to use siege towers because your units will die guaranteed. Gates have almost 0 health and can be knocked down in well under 30 seconds by some units. Not sure why these devs are having such a hard time with such simple concepts. There comes a point where its all just ridiculous. 

No chat box for multiplayer is unreasonably retarded and the multiplayer lobby for 1v1 and 2v2 etc is all yee yee jerry rigged. It doesn't take years to code a chat box with a report and block button.

Graphics are really good and the battles are good theres just a few things about the game that are annoying.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Realism, Game Design Coherence, Player Experience

review_text:
I absolutely love the total war Warhammer series. Even if you are not into Warhammer you will soon fall in love with all the different factions, armies and unit choices available. You end up spending far more money then you should on DLC's, because quite frankly some of them are amazing. 

I have spent hundreds of hours on this game, number 1 and 2 as well. Even more when they was available on game pass too. The amount of content you get with the base game is potentially hundreds of hours, and honestly it is amazing to watch thousands of cavalry demolish infantry at your control. 

Some of the best DLC's to purchase (which are regulary on sale) in my opinion are, Chaos Dwarfs, Wood Elves and the Ogre Kingdoms are loads of fun too. 

I used to love 40k as a child growing up, but never got into the fantasy side. After playing these games I have now re-started painting models after nearly 15 years off! I am obsessed with reading the old world books as well, and there is so much lore around the Warhammer fantasy.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Experience, Monetization Model

I really like the game, but unfortunately I have to give this a thumbs-down for one reason—the FPS. Compared to TW:WH2, it runs a LOT worse. With a bit of tweaking, I could get 120fps in that game, but in this, I just can't hit 60 unless I set everything to low. But doing that makes everything look like it was made out of play-dough by a 3rd grader, so I end up playing at basically 40 fps with frame dips or stutters turning the game into a slideshow.

It also seems to stutter a lot, clicking menus, building shit, opening skill trees, during battle... Basically doing anything aside from playing around in the main menu will cause a short stutter. No clue what the reason for this is, I have a pretty good cpu (i7 10700) and with msi afterburner I can see my usage is under 50% so...

review_text:
I'll be straightforward with everyone and say I do recommend the game, but I do feel as if certain issues in the game needed to either changed/altered in my personal opinion. Here are some the issues I have with the game that I'd like to see either fixed or changed.

1) The rift mechanic I feel is ok at the beginning, but as more souls are collected either by AI or the player the corruption levels are too difficult to manage or dilute. This can cause players who are looking to expand their borders a difficult time as they need at least 2 armies at the ready to close these rifts to prevent a rise in rebellion or attempt to offset overwhelming corruption. Also when rogue daemon armies spawn with 5 to 8 Soul Grinders it can be disheartening or even discouraging to want to expand as not many garrisons can even attempt to damage these armies.

2) A rework to the Supporters system for Kislev, as I personally feel that after the confederation of the opposing faction, supporters have no further use. This is especially true for Boris as once you complete the unification of KIslev, they just sit there unused. If they could be used to spend on research, growth, bolstering defenses, negating corruption, or strengthening alliances I could see potential, but as of the current state again the system is useless.

3) Bel'akor, himself, needs to be more than a generic lord as he is the first Daemon Prince of the Chaos Gods. If he is to be a future FLC lord than hopefully flesh him out more

4) After you've beaten the game, I feel as the rifts should stop spawning as there is no point since Bel'akor is defeated. If you continue past the cutscene and hope for a normal TW campaign, then stop as the rifts continue and increase in frequency making it nearly not worth playing any further.

5) Ogres need a change on how they percieved as the current tech/hoard/skaven style isnt working personally. IMO they should be a combination of Vampire Pirates, where they themselves are the camps thats you improve, while also given the same food work around as skaven. Their current state makes them very difficult to play as you need to plan ahead of time where and camp goes and how far you can move before running back to camp to replenish your food stores before attrition damage takes effect.

6) This is a hot take and very personal opinion as I know a decent bit of lore of Old World Warhammer Fantasy and AoS, but  I feel that the inclusion of Chaos Lords to fill out the respective rosters is necessary. This being Archaeon in Chaos undivided, Sigvald with Slannesh, etc. This includes human chaos worshippers into the roster to fill them out such as Chaos Knights, chariots, and range. At the same time maybe including some AoS units that are unique to each Chaos God. Also changing the status of heralds to heroes to balance armies out. That way armies can have additional casters/champions to rely on in combat like VC
Review_Angles: Gameplay Balance, Player Experience, Strategic Depth

review_text: As much as i like the formula of total war and Warhammer, I can't recommend this game any longer. Story of this game reminds me about what blizzard has done to overwatch, where the game just goes along the curve get less -> pay more. Since the publishing of the third game, all of the content they released feels like an ocean of mud, filled with bugs with sparse islands of relief (Thrones of Decay). The time to buy this game has already passed. If you want to play a cool strategy in Warhammer universe, just go play TWW2, it might have less content, but it's less buggy, feels more like a finished product and it's story ended when it should have.

review_text:
To preface this, I am only leaving a negative review because the game as is is currently broken. A host of bugs has left the AI of several factions unable to do anything. In particular the Tomb Kings and the Lizardmen. Along with other bugs, I will leave this review as negative until those bugs are fixed. I hate that this keeps happening to the best Warhammer Fantasy game out there. The people who have payed far too much money for this deserve better. 

As for the game itself. Its a good if divisive game, if your a fan of Warhammer Fantasy its the perfect game for people like us. If you're a Total War fan you'll get a lot of enjoyment out of a Total War game adapting a fantastical world. The world map is vast, the factions are incredibly varied, and the gameplay is fun if somewhat shallow. I'd recommend you get this on a steep sale though, there is a lot of DLC for this game and the prior games have not decreased in price. I'd advise you get this on a sale and give it a shot, its fun and is a great introduction to Warhammer Fantasy.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Consumer Value, Gameplay Depth

review_text: I am a 45 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 36 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2014 from his step-father, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 4 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching porn. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he said no. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had left me. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

- my old review is below;



I have bought WH3, and the dlc for the ogre kingdoms and the realm of chaos. upon launching the game and playing the prologue, i got softlocked thrice (!) preventing me from completing a turn, these softlocks where a quest battle not spawning (the wolf of dervingard) another one where right after the 1st quest objective after the conquest of dervingard, the game refused to continue and gave me no indication as to why (this indication did not exist, and ive reloaded the game 5 times, on each softlock) fixing it became a possibility only if i returned to a safe before the quest battle. the third one was another quest battle, this time the one after before, where i was shown the prompt to press R to increase unit speed, but there was no movement for the unit and as such just as before, the same softlock with the same solution occured. then i tried to play the sandbox campaign (which i loved from wh2 and was very exited for) only to have it crash after turn 13 for reasons i do not know. my pc can run wh2 easily, and meets the requirements for this one too.

for these reasons i sadly cannot recommend this game, and instead will reccomend warhammer 2, which i do enjoy. a pity because i was looking forward to playing all the new factions and the expanded map.

ive requested the refund, but sadly i was over the time (6.5 hours as of now) due to how this game plays. hopefully i still get a refund, because this game is unplayable for me.

TL:DR:
cant play due to frequent crashes and frequent softlocks. Cannot recommend. hopefully i get my €60 euro back that i spend on this game and the dlc for it.

review_text:
A very solid game in its current state, and the upcoming DLC looks promising.

Even though you need to buy the previous games and DLCs for the full(er) experience, even with just buying Total War: Warhammer III you can enjoy the game for the value you paid. Although you cannot play as the previous games' and DLCs' factions without purchasing those, you can still interact and fight against them with the starting races (Kislev, Cathay, Nurgle, Slaanesh, Khorne and Tzeentch + Be'lakor (Warriors of Chaos) in Immortal Empires).

It is very important to highlight, the Immortal Empires campaign combining the content of all three games is playable for owners of only Warhammer III as well.

The game is receiving FLC content and reworks with time, alongside the DLCs, so you are still receiving some new content if you are paying for the new DLCs or not.

Although the Warscape battle engine is always somewhat struggling in some way or form, it is rather polished, functional and enjoyable for the scope included in the Total War: Warhammer series.

The campaigns are quite enjoyable, with some exceptions, notably the late game feels rather dull and limiting in comparison to the earlier stages of campaigns because of the climate system and lack of a meaningful challenge. Scripted hostile armies spawning in completely secured territory through end game scenarios is not an enjoyable late game challenge.

With all this said, especially if you also buy the other games or DLCs you are interested in, you will have a blast in the first 100 or so turns of most of your campaigns.

From the campaigns I've played, I especially recommend playing as Katrin (Kislev) and Wulfrik the Wanderer (Norsca - paid DLC from the first game) in the Immortal Empires campaign, and I'm looking forward to a Karl Franz (Empire) campaign in the upcoming 5.0 version of the game. The Realms of Chaos campaign is not bad by any means, but the Immortal Empires campaign offers a more clean and varied fun experience.

As a conclusion, I recommend this game and I hope it will continue to receive support and new content in the years to come.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Content Accessibility, Long-term Support

review_text:
Only tech issue i had was some blurriness, which was resolved by changing anti-alias method.

The new factions are good fun, been getting lots of fun out of it, and there are many many improvements over WH2 overall.
To the point that i wouldn't be able to go back if i wanted to (Alliances, Quick Diplomacy, Reinforcement timers, Actual Settlements, settlement trading ect)

BUT, the Realm of Chaos campaign itself is very annoying. You'll get rifts spawning every 30 turns, that spew out armies agents and corruption, and you get no rewards when doing the main story, which leaves you little incentive to do so a second or third time.

The optimal way to "Win" is just capture a province or two, and just end turn until you get the rifts.

Because you are penalised if you try to expand. the only way to deal with rifts en-masse is to spam heros. and sit them at the rift spawns. which is incredibly tedious, and closing each rift costs 1500 gold if you do it this way, so it gets quite expensive.

To add to this, the AI is TERRIBLE at dealing with rifts. to the point that the entire map except your territory becomes the chaos wastes, making it even more tedious due to attrition...

REALLY keen on mortal empires, but  overall it's still a massive improvement,
Just not sure why they went for such a tedious and unrewarding main campaign. at least i could ignore the vortex.
Review_Angles: Technical Performance, Gameplay Content & Features, Campaign Design & Incentives

review_text:
I made the jump from Total War Warhammer 2 to 3 more out of curiosity than necessity. 2 is a very fine game I have sunk over a hundred hours in, and wasn’t really looking for change. But, when Immortal Empires was released I thought it was time to start the Wood Elves playthrough I always wanted to do and the new hotness was too hard to resist. 

And now I can never go back. 

It’s not just the gigantic new map with the eight new and all the old factions to fight. It’s definitely not the campaign I haven’t even started yet and that I hear so much bad things about. It’s all the little and not so little gameplay improvements that were added, all of them belonging to the category “I didn’t know I needed this, but now I can never give it up”. 

The reworked diplomacy system finally clearly communicates why certain offers are always going to be denied. The ally system allows for an even greater variety in army composition without changing the character of the faction armies too much. The millions of little changes to the battle systems make it so much easier to navigate the great battles and pull off some really stunning reversals at times. The late game crisis events that have the potential to shake up the end game grind. And, yes, the metric tons of new content helps a lot, too. 

Meanwhile the core gameplay loop is the same addictive power fantasy it always was. The production values are as atmospheric as before. Hopefully the commitment to the game by the studio will be as exemplary as it has been in the past, too. With one very substantial DLC pack already out, it sure looks that way. 

This game is a substantial improvement over Warhammer 2, without losing any of its essence. If you liked that one, absolutely go get this one.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Evolution, Content Expansion, Feature Enhancement

review_text: They are continuing to make things much better now, great game keeps on getting better with every new update ,honestly CA and total war have redeemed themselves
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Developer Support, Product Evolution

review_text:
Hands down my favorite game (and trilogy). I never write reviews, but I felt I had to for this one because I've already sunk a lot of time in it and plan on sinking even more as time goes on.

Realm of Chaos Campaign:
It's good for a play through of whatever factions you find interesting. The story picks up from the prologue so be sure to play it even if you're a total war veteran (don't worry, it's actually REALLY nice). While it's the main selling point of the game the real meat and potatoes is....

Immortal Empires:
If you own game 1 and 2, you get access to Immortal Empires, which is a gigantic world map with ALL factions from ALL three games in it available to play. If the faction is a DLC, you must own the DLC, obviously. This is where the game truly shines and provides thousands of hours of playtime. As of writing there's a total of 86(!) playable Legendary Lords (factions). You want to paint the world map with your colors via world domination? Create an alliance superpower? Rid the world of the evil Chaos factions? Rid the world of Order factions as the Chaos factions? Assert Elven supremacy as the High elves? This is where you do it.

As per Total War, the secret sauce is the enjoyable mix of a turn-based strategy on the campaign map (where you move armies, do diplomacy, etc.) and real time battles. No other game to my knowledge does this as well as Total War.

Couple all this with the fantastic universe that is Warhammer Fantasy and this game is just..*chef's kiss*. As a Warhammer fan, this game has been a dream for decades.

The game did launch a bit rocky (Realm of Chaos campaign) but was fixed and changed a bit according to player feedback.
There are also some bugs that the devs are aware of, specifically in the Immortal Empires which is why they label it as a Beta. They are constantly tweaking and fixing issues that crop up as they create a truly massive and one of a kind experience.

The modding community is fantastic, with hundreds of mods available to suite your specific tastes and needs.

With the amount of content available for this game (and more coming every 3-6 months), the price is well worth it if you are at all a total war fan, Warhammer fan, or fantasy fan.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Content, Narrative Integration

review_text:
The core gameplay is still good, just as in TW:WH2, New units are fun and the new race mechanics introduced (Food, Chaos devotion etc.) are also solid and playable. 
But the main Campaign mechanic is incredibly unfun, in some aspects downright unfair and massively decreases replayability. Even races which shouldn't care about Ursun (Ogres and Cathay) are forced into the Chaos Realm Mechanic, which continuosly hogs your main army. Because the AI has an unfair advantage in the chaos realms in some aspects, you can't just ignore this main mechanic. This decreases replayability with other races, because your win conditions are always the same. 
Add on this the instability of the game (Alt+Tab can crash it, currently it crashes often when you want to resolve a Battle manually) and it can't be recommended in its current state.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Replayability, Technical Stability

review_text:
###Update3### - A mere 12months later and CA are back to their old ways and leaving the game in a broken state while they get ready for more paid DLC. Seems like we will never reach the peak experience from TWWH2.

Won't be buying any future Total War games if this game is the standard for how they treat there flagship titles.

###Update2### - CA through some frequent updates over the last 6months have tried to win back some community favour with bug fixing and content updates to previously sold DLC. It's a nice gesture and while i feel like the game is in a good place i fear the damage to community has been done. I would recommend the game now in it's current state, however i don't believe this game will reach it's original potential of being the greatest warhammer total war in the series so. That title still appears to be held by it's predecessor.

###Update1### - So the game has been out for over a year and a half now and while the released content for the game has been very good, CA seem to have abandoned fixing any long term bugs in this game in place for releasing what is now over priced DLC for small amounts of content.

In addition to the lack of bug fixing and to justify the DLC prices CA have come out in a blog post and basically said "buy the dlc or we take the game in the backyard shoot it in the face and bury it next to Three Kingdoms".

In CA eyes, they realises that currently there are enough 'whales' in the community with money that just take the 'shut up and take my money' approach and buy all their DLCs regardless of price at this point. i'm looking at this game now and feel disgusted at the level CA have gone to for financial gain at the expensive of their fans. But while there blog post to justify this is shameful and tone deaf, I still don't expect CA will change this process until the long term effects of this are fully realised from a financial perspective. The community is in uproar about the blog post response to these pricing concerns and rightly so and in the long term its going hurt CA, their business, the fans and the future dlcs and other total war releases. I've been playing total war games and loved them for a very long time, but will be taking my money and time elsewhere if things don't change and i expect the other total war  fans will eventually move on to other games and some will never return. 

###Original thoughts at release###
Great potential here, but flawed at release after being a major step back from the previous game in almost every aspect, The recent patch and update (DLC) is a step in the right direction so if that trend continues with future patches and updates there will be a very good game here in the next 4-6 months. Until then i'd recommend sticking with Total War: Warhammer 2 if you have that as that games experience is still exceptionally better than what this game has to offer.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Developer Accountability

review_text:
Well......I certainly got MY money's worth out of the game but as a new player trying to get in....dang it really is a lot of money, sort of like a Paradox game with a million DLCs. I bought all this stuff drips and drabs over the last 8 or 9 years. But to buy this all at once? Yeesh. You will want the first two games as their content all snowballs into this title; meaning the races introduced in the first two games and whatever dlcs you picked will be playable right out of the box in addition to the warhammer 3 base factions if you buy this game (you don't need to keep warhammer 1 and 2 installed at least, thank goodness). If you don't own either of the first two you will only get the base warhammer 3 factions. As such, I can really only recommend this game on sale simply because there is just so much to buy. A good chunk of the DLC factions ARE pretty good too.

 The modding scene is really good on these games and I HIGHLY recommend the SFO mod. Just filter by "top rated all time" in the workshop and there's easily 5-10 pages of 5 star mods to look at. SFO is a great one-stop compilation though, doesn't add a bunch of useless fluff for the sake of adding it either; its all tasteful stuff in my opinion. Theres a lot of modded races you can add as well if you can't afford the DLC factions. Cataph's mods, Mixu's faction unlocker, Immortal Empires Expanded, The Old World Campaign, SCCP additional factions, OVN Lost factions. Hell there's a mod to be a nation of giant crabs. Get the Better Camera mod too, thank me later.

So what of the actual gameplay? These games takes place in two distinct spheres; the campaign map and the battlefield. The campaign map is a turn-based affair where you will manage your towns by constructing buildings in your allotted building slots, the number of which are governed by your population size/growth. So you have to decide do you want buildings that produce trade goods versus expanding the types of troops you can recruit as an example. Your towns themselves have to have their public order managed on a sliding scale of -100 to +100, and many factions have a corruption type and environment that they naturally spread/prefer to kinda terraform the land to their liking in a way which is pretty interesting. A couple of towns together in pre-determined geographic areas make up "provinces" and once you control all towns in a province you can issue an edict to give that whole province a buff. The capital town/city of each province can become bigger and have more building slots and get better defensive walls and higher-tier units. On the campaign map you will also recruit troops which go into army "stacks" that must be headed by a "lord". Each troop stack can have 20 units, including the Lord. These stacks can be moved around the map and even enter different stances so you can force-march them to get a bit more movement range, a raiding stance to steal gold or food in enemy territory, an ambush stance in difficult terrain to get the jump on the enemy......stuff like that. You can research technologies and engage in diplomacy with different tabs on the campaign map. You can also level up and equip gear to the Lords leading your armies.

When your stack(s) bump into enemy stacks, a pitched battle on that physical spot of earth takes place in that the game will send you through a loading screen and then into a whole other half of the game where you assume command of your military stack in real-time and guide them to victory. This is really where the Total War franchise has always stood out; offering battles the scale of which no other games really even get close too. Your units that you built and shoved in here? Oh yea, ONE unit might be 120 dinosaur-men wielding axes or spears. Another unit might be just one guy but its a whole entire dragon at your command. Maybe you built some sick siege equipment. Some factions get some crazy ish like warp lightning cannons (great for taking out aforementioned dragons heh) and my personal fave: Hellstorm Rocket batteries lolol. You can have FORTY units on screen under your command at once and thats not even including whatever the enemy is throwing at you so you could easily have 6000 - 8000 models on screen at once all INDIVIDUALLY fighting each other to where you can zoom in to their perspective on the ground and watch them fight and see their individual animations. It's insane. Zooming in to watch your undead Cairn Wraiths, ghost mfers with scythes riding skeleton horses, charging in to a flank and just demolishing some poor infantry unit. Or watching the previously mentioned siege equipment bombarding the enemy from their own perspective never gets old. In a rather loose way; its a rock, paper, scissors formula in that spearmen beat cavalry, cavalry beat infantry that dont have spears, missile units tear up anything until something gets in their face, heavy infantry can beat most other things once they bog them down enough but can be flanked and beaten by other things. Flying units are generally susceptible to missiles but scare the piss out of infantry when they land and start whooping ass. But then again.....this game has so many factions with weird niche exceptions and specialist units that its a little more complicated than that. You'll get the hang of it. It can be quite a bit to manage because on top of all these units....your Lords have special abilities and you may have a mage or two in your stack that can straight up cast spells. 

I could go on all day about this game. Graphics are good, performance is good untill you break the game with so much crap on screen it slows everything down lol. Audio is good for sound effects and forgettable for actual music. The faction variety gives a ton of replayability because of their wildly differing unit rosters and faction mechanics that have gotten better and better over time from Warhammer 1 until now.

Two last points. First, I have had an enormous amount of fun playing multiplayer co-op campaigns and if you have a good friend, or THREE who will spend the time with you, its friggin awesome. You all take your turns simultaneously now which is a huge improvement over warhammer 1 and 2. When your buddy wants to fight a battle on the battle map, they can gift you units to control so you all can actively participate and not sit there bored. Its actually a great way to learn to mico units by having your friend give you just the spellcasters or just the cavalry to manage. 

Last point; USE THE FOLLOWING DIFFICULTY SETTINGS!!!! For Campaign difficulty set it to easy or medium to learn the game. But for the battles, you should set it to Normal or Hard. It is crucial you DO NOT EVER SET BATTLE DIFFICULTY TO EASY! Why? Because it doesn't actually change the difficulty of the AI, all it does is make your auto-resolve battle option ridiculously easy by effectively multiplying the power of your army by a factor of 2.5 or 3....why is this bad? Because then when you go try to fight a battle yourself, you no longer get that multiplier, it ONLY applies to how your auto-resolved battles will go. This means, that as a new player you will get a worse result commanding the battle yourself EVERY TIME and discourage yourself and/or resign yourself to NEVER commanding any of the battles, meaning you effectively miss out on learning HALF OF THE GAME! Note; Normal battle difficulty has this problem as well but less so, it gives you like a 30 or 40 percent strength calculation for auto-resolves. Thus the recommended battle setting is actually HARD so the auto-resolve calculator finally tells you the damn truth about your chances commanding it yourself.

EDIT: I'm changing my review to negative until you idiots at CA fix the AI bug making multiple factions sit around and do nothing. Unacceptable by this point in the game's life cycle and unacceptable for a company making similar games for 20 years. And eff you for making LegendofTotalWar upset.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Financial Accessibility, Content Integration

review_text: This game offers more content than TWWH2, but all of it less polished and feels worse. Units are unresponsive, bugs are everywhere, performance is terrible. A lack of consistent bug fixing, quality of life updates, or communication at all from the devs has let the game stagnate. Recently, Creative Assembly has decided to increase the price of DLC by 150% for less content in the Shadows of Change DLC, which will be the first DLC EVER for this series I have not purchased. You should buy a Paradox game instead.

review_text:
Greedy, incompetent company that are out of touch and overvalue themselves.

They took the money that their most loyal customers for their most niche market (which they have monopolised) have paid without question, and wasted big part of it on something that they have never done before: online battle royale shooter with loot boxes.

This would've been fine if CA had track record of fixing the issues and not be slimy with their corporate greed that is so bad that even their parent company had to put a stop to a train wreck of the project.
Company thinks they are a super star, a hot shot, big boss, or whatever they are, yet they are nothing but a shell of its former glory, all built with the genre that they have full grasp.

Clearly it seems like Sega held the management to be in charge of laying off their 40% of work force and they just decided to lay off those that do not fit with their agenda.

Of course Total War community is not a group of angels, it is full of toxic people that can't seem to grasp the idea of common sense, and hide behind incognito to do some heinous shit to anyone that may have involvement with CA. However, the way they have been handling many of their issues have been down right atrocious and current drama is basically the last straw that broke the camel's back.

DO NOT buy this or ANY games from Creative Assembly, but if you are really inclined to do so, I would be very careful about it. This company has shut down the support of games that are extremely popular (3K total war), shut down the communication of any valid criticism and run their mouth about how it is a "privilege" for a PAYING CUSTOMERS to critique their game.
In addition, they have been up-charging their products, like DLC, Total War Sagas all the while their technical debt on each game is constantly increasing with every patch.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Corporate Ethics, Product Direction

CA just released the Road Map for the next year and absolutely nothing mentions an overhaul for Norsca.

Let me reiterate, a game 1 faction, that has never been majorly updated outside of balancing, is still not receiving any rework or planned overhaul.

They have a limited roster, 2 LL, and each campaign consists of the same "getting pinned in Norsca" even though Wulfrik is supposed to be WANDERING

It's been 6 YEARS since they were released, and for the longest time you couldn't even play them on the second game.

I am not spending another cent on this game until they get updated.

review_text:
I have played since shogun 2. Know whats changed since then? Very little and thats kind of the motto with CA. 

Do as little as possible because you have no competitors. It used to be the way that new games changed the formula in some interesting way. Advances in tec had developers constantly pushing limits to make bigger and better games, improvements to the formula and new things to play with. If you guys played company of heroes, lets just think about how in COH2 they added ice that you could blow up to sink tanks. what did CA do? Well in Attila you could set buildings on fire during sieges. 

But for the longest time, you STILL can't fully destroy castle walls, theirs always an invulnerable nub of the wall left standing. 
God forbid you man your walls in a siege because telling your units to get off the wall takes them 5 business days. 
Units aren't responsive. God forbid you tell your handgunners to shoot something to the side of them, they'll think about it and instead of just turning and shooting the whole damn unit moves and then gl gg if they decide they dont want to shoot.
You can't put cannons on the walls still. 
The pathing is still trash, a bunch of archers running the opposite direction to your horses? Sounds like the exact thing cavalry was made for, except instead of running them over and moving on with their day they engage the back row and slow down because now the entire 60 horses are in "Combat". 
Flying units suck because the annoying sync animations don't really favour flying units. 
Large units getting stuck on 1 enemy because yes mr player I know you want your Godzilla to run over there but this spear man is on double pay. 
Difficulty is still just cheats for the AI, nothing interesting to see here. 
End game crisis? lol. Instead of something thematic and interesting like oh idk, Stellaris? You get a million armies spawn out of thin air with the most annoying army comps. Destroyed the vampire counts did you? Well lets just spawn them back in around their old capitol that you arent defending. That's fun and totally makes sense instead of.. Spawning them in for the factions still alive?

Most of these issues have been here since Rome 2 and frankly I gave up after Attila because it was already stale. It's simple CA, your next game better have a brand new engine or you can bet your bottom dollar i'm not buying it and if you care about getting good games that are worth your hard earned money and the overall health of the RTS gaming scene you wont buy it either.
Review_Angles: Historical Progression, Gameplay Innovation, Competitive Market Dynamics

review_text:
I'm not a fan of Warhammer lore, but the game design of TW:WH3 has made it my favorite TW game to play of late (despite my deep love of Rome II)

- The unique campaign mechanics for each faction makes it fun and varied to play
- The faction armies are, of course, wildly different, creating interesting asymmetry in every game

And, of course, simultaneous turns and up to 8 players is a GAME CHANGER
Total War multiplayer campaigns have always been a slog waiting for the other player's turn to end, so WH3 with friends (even just 1 friend) feels so much punchier
I beg you, CA, seriously consider bringing this feature to all new games, because it is practically a necessity in my opinion.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Variety, Multiplayer Experience, Feature Innovation

review_text:
I own every game in the franchise, nearly 1200 hours across the three Warhammer games and I would say that Total war has and will be my forever games. 

That being said this toxic pricing model, the cold messaging put out by the developers, and the lack of content for $25 dollars is insulting to someone like me and probably you reading this who has stood by this company through the good and bad times. 

Avoiding politics because its dumb the worlds economy is hurting in every country right now and gaming is an outlet that many people like myself turn too for some solace. 

For this company to recognize that and claim "higher operating costs" as a reason for almost doubling the price of a lord pack  that has half the content per lord followed by a veiled threat to brick the game is a slap in my face. I will not be buying this DLC and I own every DLC they have put out for the last 8 years. 

I want to send them the message with my wallet because that is the only thing these people understand and you should do the same if you feel at all similar to how I do right now.

review_text:
Hello there, let me tell you why this "review bombing" is justified after 18 months of lousy product support:

    Campaign map AI utterly sucks, unable to put up a proper fight, build/upgrade up its armies or effectively develop its empires.
    Diplomacy mechanics and diplomacy AI in all ways & forms is beyond awful, especially around vassals and alliances
    AI is bugged/limited in its perception of nearby faction (AI is literally not aware what factions are nearby [no diplomatic contact]).
    unit pathing in manual battles, especially cities with construct-able barricades, is awful
    units refusing to path through broken city gates & destroyed city walls, instead insisting on using ladders to slowly climb up & exhaust themselves.
    cavalry/monsters getting models stuck, which pulls back the whole unit into death.
    units dropping/forgetting orders, even in the middle of pitched melee combat
    units not shooting because they are "moving fast" while being stationary
    units unable to shoot despite having clear Line Of Sight
    battle maps being broken for pathing and LOSight, especially on top of wall crenellations
    auto-resolve insists on damaging & killing Single-entity-monsters and especially artillery pieces, even when the player army outnumbers the enemy 5 to 1.
    auto-resolve still gives cities a ridicilous advantage, even when the player army outnumbers the enemy minor settlement garrison 5 to 1.
    certain units & lords/heroes fail to properly do their charging attack
    units (especially large ones) will randomly die when attacking certain walls/gates, or being remotely in proximity of a collapsing wall (but nowhere near close enough for it to be a valid danger).
    units (even lords on foot) will randomly die when climbing ladders.
    some lords (cathay dragons especially) just flat out fail to perform melee attacks for well over 10 seconds at a time.
    AI does not understand nor properly react during the defense of siege battles, it will spread out its army across the map and be unable to fight a concentrated force.
    AI charging his fastest units at the start of battle into certain death, especially lords/heroes like Belakor
    AI clueless about properly using AOE magic & magic in general, which also makes anything "anti magic" rather useless
    hundreds of bugs related to skills, techs, items, unit abilities/stats, building mechanics etc etc.
    sometimes two characters (lords/heroes) will be placed on the exact same coordinates on the campaign map, permanenetly preventing them from movement and interaction.
    Item qualities being nonsense, with common ones often being better than rare/special ones.
    lord/hero traits either not working or straight up inferior compared to other available ones.
    WOChaos revive norsca faction mechanic intentionally broken by CA because they could not be bothered to properly fix it.
    Manual battle AI will sometimes simply not activate, instead its units refuse to attack/defend/move. Seen most often in ambush battles and wood elf forest defense battles.
    Countless quests for lord items or unlocking special lords/heroes do not work properly
    AI occasionally able to see your ambush/hidden armies from across immense distances & react to their positioning
    skirmish mode on ranged units often failing to trigger/react, causing the ranged unit to just stand still
    AI will often prioritize targeting, sabotaging or annoying the player even if it means certain doom for its faction.
    player units are utterly unable to finish off a broken leadership/fleeing unit, especially if it is a single entity like a foot lord.
    squads of large-sized ranged units (like salamander/razordon hunting packs) after finishing a move order will take forever to "wiggle around" before actually firing
    confederated lords for factions that have loyalty mechanics (skaven etc) will often start at zero loyalty.
    confederated lords will sometimes not be able to change their mounts
    confederated Legendary lords will sometimes lack their immortality trait, meaning their next death is permanent.
    Completely non-functional mechanic for automatic development of cities (everyone forgot this even exists in game because it never worked)
    AI lacking any proper skill builds for most lords and heroes, which both makes them weaker and makes those lords useless for confederation.
    bugs related to construct-able objects on defensive maps, where units get stuck in barricades or can not attack them
    fresh bugs like bretonia damsels, wood elf ariel, nakai unit recruitment etc etc.
    Black Ark unique map army spawn positions AGAIN bugged, after it was fixed in late Tww 2
    Black Ark capability to offer recruitment to nearby DElf armies bugs out when the Black Ark is garrisoned in a city.
    AI will readily kill its own armies by trying to occupy ruins that have just been destroyed by extremely unfriendly (but not yet at war) factions which are still surrounding that location (from the previous turns razing).
    AI will readily abandon its capital city and flee to some meaningless tier 1 settlement when facing an equal force (instead of fighting where its chance is best, inside the capitol).
    some sea objects (like islands/treasure/skull/carcass) will cause a guaranteed crash to desktop
    AI will insist on besieging a weak settlement for 10 turns despite outnumbering & overpowering the garrison 5 to 1, and auto-resolve showing certain defeat for the players city.
    various lord/hero equippable ancillaries that fail to work properly
    Vampire Count/Coast UI for showing raise dead pool possibilities (near city bar UI) does not show units recruit-able from battle casualties.
    certain unique Cathay Caravan rewards are again inaccessible, despite being "fixed" in some previous patch (such as the vampire weapon).
    there is a limited number of names for generic lords/heroes, and once they have all been used up the game notifications will start showing nonsense (mixing up factions, names & icons etc).
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, AI Competence

review_text:
Its Warhammer plain and simple. if you liked Warhammer 1 and Warhammer 2 Total War you will love the third installement. it improves on almost all aspects from the first 2 installements in the series. from the units to magic to the connectivity in multiplayer matches or campaigns. 8 player simultanious campaigns is a step in the right direction in almost every way and i hope that it continues for future titles in the total war series.
Now why am i giving it a negative review? Well its mostly due to issues that i have had with this series since the first installement. DOOM STACKS everywhere, to win you need doom stacks of the same 1-2 units with the same buffs over and over again. i personnally dont find such army compositions fun or interesting. 
I also dislike the Magic in the game. i completely get that its part of Warhammer in every way, i just dont like using it nor having it used on me. i feel it breaks the possibility of trying to use tactics in combat when random chunks of meteors just spawn out of the sky. As I've said above i get its part of warhammer and i was willing to live with it but tie that with the Doom Stacks meta and i just can't.
ever since Immortal Empires has been released ive tried playing my favorite faction, the Dwarves. Can i just say they have Fucked it up hard. the book of Grudges is completely broken. on turn 1 with every Dwarven faction ive played they start with 8+ Grudges scattered across the map. after about 20 turns your already losing a lot of public order in your lands due to the grudge system. It forces you to try and rush targets that will completely overextend you in every way. not to mention most Grudges are on settlements of other major factions. 

Yes my review here is basically me just being mad at aspects that have been a part of the Warhammer series since Warhammer 1. i was usually able to ignore most of these issues and having a blast in MP. I am unable to Ignore them now and it completely kills any enjoyment i have tried to have with this game.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Balance, Series Evolution, Multiplayer Experience

review_text:
User: Haza 2/17/2020

Hello, I'm a big fan of the franchise, in particular the Warhammer series. I think they are great games, and you all did a fantastic job translating that fun and interesting setting into a video game.
I have been wondering, though, why are all the humans white or Chinese in the games as of now? I understand that the setting was centered on the Old World. And I don't expect any halfhearted diversification of, say, the Empire or Bretonnia; Obviously, it wouldn't make sense in the setting and probably just ** off the fascists in the GW fanbase.
But I am curious if the lack of racial diversity within human factions is something you've thought of, something which concerns you, or something you plan to change in the future? As a non-white gamer and fantasy lover, I've always been disappointed by how white the most popular fantasy universes are. Be it Warhammer or LoTR, they center white people as the baseline for what "human" means, and often have those white people fight races of inhuman monsters and corrupt men who may or may not be based on racist real world stereotypes (the Easterlings and Haradrim in LoTR; the Skaven, to me, could read as an analog for the Nazi's perceptions of jews infiltrating society with criminal conspiracies).
Of course, I know you all didn't create these worlds, but, given the increasingly global nature of the Warhammer games, I would really like to see more human factions based on African or Middle eastern cultures. Perhaps something like a Wakanda-like nation taking the fight to Chaos.
I recognize it could be hard to make respectfully, seeing as what I know of the original GW lore portrays these cultures in a way that's often a little stereotypical... but given the ridiculousness of the setting I don't think it would be too hard to adjust and expand the canon so that it is respectful, but still over-the-top and fun, like Bretonnia and the Empire.
I know that this is a just a videogame, and not that important in the grand scheme of things. But I think there was an excellent opportunity in game 3 to subvert the, in my view quite harmful, trope of ultra-whiteness/eurocentrism in high fantasy.
Review_Angles: Narrative Authenticity, Representation & Inclusivity, Franchise Fidelity

review_text:
Changing my review from negative to positive. Almost a year later, Warhammer III is finally enjoyable as a game. The release of immortal empires changed everything from the get go, even if it was a little bit of a mess starting out. Many months later, the game runs much better, feels better to play, and is quite satisfying to paint the gigantic map that is the completed Old World. The barrier to new players has been dropped by allowing IE access without buying a million DLC. It seems that after some quite intense backlash and drama, CA is finally listening to the community.

All this to say, while the development process is slow and sometimes tedious, this game is on it's way to surpassing Warhammer II. The replay-ability is already there with dozens of Legendary Lords to play. There are some factions that need some updating/reworking (Dwarfs, Dark Elves, Ogres, Demon Prince/Daniel, Kugath, etc.)... But as it stands every faction is a viable pick. It's a fun game, and if you are a fan of total war or are even slightly interested in Warhammer fantasy, I can confidently recommend TWW3, especially on sale!
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Long-term Development

review_text:
Update Feb 25: Alright they got there. Still not as good as the underlying game play of Pharaoh but worth the buy.

Update August 2023: later patches introduced new bugs. I haven’t touched the game in months. I wish I could recommend it. 
—
Patch has resolved mymain issues.  I'm ok to recommend the game as it stands as of Patch 1.31 (July 2022).
---
This game is pretty incredible.  The factions are well thought out.  The map and battles are gorgeous.  

BUT the overarching campaign is not very fun. You hardly get to use your faction leader, because they're always stuck in some hellhole, taking attrition, to move the story forward.  When you finally get to it, the end battle is not auto-resolvable and way too punishing, even on the easiest setting, despite all battles leading up to this one being fairly straightforward, either via auto resolve or by fighting manually.  There are enough bugged collisions where units get stuck on defense structures, and you absolutely need them to win, so they sit there, dying slowly, while you can do nothing. It's hard to tell if this battle is so hard because of faction imbalance - maybe my army structure wasn't suited for the final battle - but if that's the case, why was this army melting everything else it faced? Poor design.

Worse yet, the 'intercept faction about to win' thing seems to be bugged, so you just lose, despite getting a warning that you're about to lose and need to fight. And if you lose the campaign because another faction beats you in this dumb race, there's no option to play on.  

Great game concept, totally ruined by the forced end game where its central features are bugged.  I can't overstate how frustrated I am by the mechanics of the campaign and the 'survival battle' concept.  So, so misguided. Now I'll probably walk away for a day and try again, only to come back and deal with the same issue...just like last time.

So, wait for a big patch or two to solve these issues.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, Content Quality

review_text:
This game has the foundation to be absolutely incredible! There is a total rework to town battles that make even minor settlement defense/offense infinitely more interesting. They REALLY improved the global map movement always allowing you to move your max distance in any stance, this is really only big in the encampment stance. The factions (for chaos/evil) are really cool, interesting, and flavorful! I am the type of player, I struggle enjoying the "good guys" even in TW2.

With all of this said, there is more debugging and Quality of Life improvements to get the A.I up to code with where warhammer total war 2 currently is. Remember when considering this game, the second has years worth of development into it after hitting market and this has months so far. They cannot copy/paste everything into this game esp with all the great updates they did!  What that means though, is that they have devs that already know how to fix those problems, so in time this game will be ABSOLUTELY INSANE! My rating for the current state of the game without comparison is 8/10, and 6/10 with comparison.  The moment they fix the AI and minor bugs, the game will be easily 9.5/10. Then if they get all the previous factions with the new mechanics 10/10, redefining moment for the genre!

If you are going to buy this game comparing it to their predecessor, you likely won't enjoy it yet. If you buy this game for the joy of a new game, you will likely love this game!
Review_Angles: Gameplay Innovation, Faction Design & Appeal, Technical Polish & AI Maturity

review_text:
This game was a mess at launch. The original campaign for the game("Realms of Chaos") is just as awful and borderline unplayable today as it was on launch. The community largely overlooked this with the release of the grand campaign tying all three Total War: Warhammer games together. 

Bugs have been many, and patches have been few and far between. Many things are plagued by horrible design decisions(such as the campaign mechanics for the Ogre Kingdoms) and haven't even been touched since launch a year and half ago. 

For many, the gigantic 150% price hike for the forthcoming Shadows of Change are too much, and I agree. In some ways it is offering us less content than DLC that have released earlier at less than half the price. Creative Assembly and Sega are not serious about improving the game. They are not serious about revisiting bad design decisions, fixing bugs, or even giving quality content in paid DLC. This is about the most cynical price gouging I've seen in a game in many years.

To **** with this company. I strongly recommend against buying any games or DLC from Creative Assembly until there has been a concrete and demonstrated commitment to changing things.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Consumer Value, Game Design

review_text:
The game had its issues at launch which the devs have spent a little over 2 years trying to rectify now.

The most recent update (5.0) has finally got the game into a good state, and the latest DLC accompanying it is one of the best they've made for the series.

The game still has its issues (mostly revolving around the AI and lack of interesting end game), but they only really become noticable once you've got hundreds of hours in the series, by which point you'll have gotten more than your money's worth.

If you've been holding off on getting game 3, it's definitely worth picking up now. If you're completely new to the Total War Warhammer games, there's plenty of content in game 3 alone to justify picking it up without having touched the previous games.
Review_Angles: Post-Launch Development, Consumer Value, Game State Assessment

review_text:
[b]Total War: Warhammer III - A Mixed Experience with a Recommendation[/b]

Rating: ★★★☆☆

Total War: Warhammer III presents a mixed experience that may appeal to dedicated fans of the series but may not be worth it for everyone. With its continuation of the grand strategy and fantastical battles, this game offers some enjoyable moments, but falls short in certain areas.

While the game maintains the immersive Warhammer universe and introduces new factions, it lacks significant innovation compared to its predecessors. The campaign can feel repetitive and lacks enough fresh mechanics to keep players fully engaged.

However, if you can find Total War: Warhammer III at a discounted price, particularly under $20, it may be worth considering for fans of the series. Despite its flaws, it still offers the iconic battles and strategic depth that the franchise is known for.

Overall, if you are a dedicated fan of the Total War series and can acquire the game at a lower price point, Total War: Warhammer III may be worth a purchase. However, for those looking for groundbreaking improvements or a completely new experience, it may not be worth investing in at full price.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Innovation, Series Continuity

review_text:
Somehow, CA thinks it is a privilege for us to use a public forum to tell them they have more rot and corruption than a Nurgling with super AIDS. This is not even to mention the absolutely unfair and unjustified DLC price gauging that has been going on for years now while they can't even fix basic problems in the base game. 
Unless there is a top down restructuring of this company, and until all the rot has been cut out, I will never buy another CA product, game, or DLC. I would encourage anybody else reading this review to do the same.  They do not deserve our money.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Corporate Ethics, Technical Stability

review_text:
Update 10/6/25: I have decided that CA has had too many chances in general and I'm giving up this series. A fair warning to anybody looking to get into this series, Creative Assembly does not care about their players. They care about how much money they can squeeze out of them before they say boo, so have fun being a part of that game of tug-of-war if you decide to buy.

Creative Assembly have failed to keep their product in working order for months on end at this point. All while developing new, paid DLC. I will not speculate on the internal problems that are evident, but this is unacceptable from a company that still views TWH3 as a top revenue stream. This review will be updated after the game is stable for 6 months, as consistency is something CA has shown to have problems with.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Corporate Ethics

review_text:
If you love Warhammer for the lore and the battle, and/or you have a hard time getting tabletop games going, this will absolutely help you lean into your addiction while letting you get into the world from a different angle. The game may have had a rocky start on day 1, but the UI is far improved, the bugs have been largely squashed, and with the advent of Immortal Empires, Warhammer 3 is looking to become one of the best PC games (and certainly one of the best strategy games) of 2022, despite itself. 

The only gripe I can really speak to is that the often extremely heavy lore and the unchallenged brutality of the setting are sometimes tossed to the wind in favor of bowing to societal pressures from all fronts: Money, politics, fear of censorship, etc. Regardless of whatever slot one sits in on the political spectrum, adaptations can still be true to what the source material was/is and be tastefully done without being dismissive of entire aspects of whole factions and races within a work of fiction. Creative Assembly clearly, however unfortunately, said, "Yes Daddy," to Games Workshop pushing for the models and story/stories to be closer in line with the more whimsical, kid-friendly approach to their fantasy world in the Age of Sigmar reboot. It serves to make for a less honest adaptation of a world that until late resembled the prejudices, inhumanity (pun not intended, but very much approved. Bc Elves. And Daemons.), and endless violence of our own world in a way that was more palatable, but still very much disquieting and thought provoking. 

Sort of the point of fantasy and fictitious storytelling of any kind, isn't it? To serve as metaphor for our own existence? Life is spooky after all, and sometimes we might need to relate to a character in a fantasy world to be able to navigate the fuckery of the one we live in. 

Or MAYBE it's 5am,  my brain has been hijacked by coke-addled squirrels, and/or I'm actually 3 red pandas in a trench coat. WHO KNOWS. I'll ask the moving-induced sleep deprivation.

TL;DR: Everything is on fire, Cheese, games, sex, and booze are the only good things left in the world, and Warhammer 3 is pretty dope, but not as dope as you, random citizen (Not you, Chet/Chad/Tad... Put. The Meta. Down. Put it down.) Anyway, Hail Slaanesh, death to the Asur, and long live Malekith, and yay "M" ratings. 

Let The End Times Roll.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Narrative Authenticity

review_text:
Not many hours in, but I can see already that this is a completely different animal compared to TWW2.
I am very impressed by the game's performance and optimization, and by the crazy idea that is Immortal Empires.

Otherwise, I would be writing here the same review I wrote for TWW, or no review at all.

There are few games out there that offer this level of graphical quality, even less that are optimized to this degree. Probably none that offers a campaign as comprehensive and as ambitious as Immortal Empires.

If you have the hardware, the money, the 100GB of disk space, and the prohibitive amount of time (probably 100 hours for the tutorial alone), then this is a unique game that you absolutely have to try.

The game's graphical quality is something subjective. The performance and optimization though, are pretty objective and measurable. The game includes one of the most deterministic benchmarks in the industry (TWW2 wasn't bad either).

The game menu offers pretty much all the graphical settings you may want this gen, and it detects my Rx 6000 out of the box and its features, unlike TWW2. I am getting very similar (-5 to -8) FPS to TWW2 benchmark, all settings maxed.

The problem with TWW2 were the crashes, and the deal breaker were crashes in-battle. So far no crashes in TWW3 in a very short play time, but also with this level of optimization, it is hard for me to imagine. TWW2 had my power supply begging for mercy. If I get a crash, I will update my review otherwise.

I have to first of all applaud the work of Feral here, achieving numbers on par with Windows and sometimes better, depending on how bloated your installation was in the first place. Moreover, now that this game has been free-to-play, we can now see and measure by ourselves. I wonder, what the experiences of Mac users have been.
Review_Angles: Technical Performance & Optimization, Content Scope & Ambition, Hardware & Time Investment

review_text:
Before version 2.0: This game was good but held back by a questionable game mechanics, to the point it wasn't really worth playing it.

After version 2.0: This is the ultimate Warhammer and Total war experience, the culmination of all the fantastic work that Creative Assembly has done throughout the trilogy. The vast variety of factions, each with their own mechanics and each legendary lord within their faction adding their own spin onto it again provides an incredible amount of variety of gameplay. 

The newest factions part of Warhammer 3 are all well made and vastly different to each other - including existing factions, this game also features probably the best tutorial of the entire series which really gives a great intro to the whole over-arching storyline. Most will however enjoy the Immortal Empires campaign far more than anything else, which is still in beta but in a good palce.

Highly recommend this for any Warhammer (as this is probably the best warhammer game out there) and Total War fans.

10/10
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Content Variety, Tutorial Quality

review_text:
Review at Patch: Launch
Hours Clocked: 24.4

NOTE: This review is mostly tailored to people familiar with the series. If this is not your first Total War, and/or First Total War: Warhammer game, I would look to a different review that covers the basics of the series.

I have been looking forward to Total War: Warhammer III for a while, so when I finally get to play it I dived right in. The Prologue Campaign was pretty good. While it was mostly on rails, the story was engaging enough that despite it being a prolonged tutorial, I found it worth playing through.

If you're familiar with the series, there's not a whole lot to be said. Some changes to sieges makes do change up the routine, but overall it is what you expect to get in terms of gameplay and variety from various factions. If you've been happy with the series, you'll find some usual gripes about one thing or another. Aside from the possibility the performance of the game might be vastly different, nothing stands out that is overwhelmingly different from prior entries.

The Factions have been fun to play and the Campaign seems faster paced than it was in Total War: Warhammer II. Timing when you do certain things does have some risk/reward element and unlike the previous Campaigns, this one feels more dynamic for better or for worse. Again, if you're familiar with the series, once you dial in the needed pacing, the game will feel familiar.

The game is not without quirks and flaws. The additions to sieges leave some things to be desired. The AI really doesn't handle you making complicated split attacks well. I've found it incredibly easy to cheese attacking settlements by splitting up my forces and the AI won't react accordingly and leaves whole sections undefended, even if that's where your main host is.

Diplomacy as usual has some bizarre highs and lows. While Slaanesh has a powerful ability to just outright "buy" a vassal, the fact you cannot be allied when you do it is frankly an odd choice. You can kick them and quickly grab them, but it takes 10 turns for the cooldown and on top of it, you take a penalty for the carefully managed long game of converting allies, not to mention it just feels like that goes against the point. Some high points is that because of the map, it seems like if you put in the work, you can get some interesting alliances if you put the time into it.

My specs are listed below, and I had no issue playing the game. To me, the performance feels similar to the previous entries in the series. While this worked for me, a buddy that I play co-op with did not have the same experience, but I am not sure what his specs are. However, since my buddy and I normally have similar experiences, for this particular game I will note that your mileage may vary.

Overall my recommendation of Total War: Warhammer III is Recommended.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*]It's more of what you'd expect from Total War: Warhammer.
    [*]I appreciate some of the new additions to sieges.
    [*]The new factions are fun to play, and so far every Chaos Faction feels different enough to stand on their own.
    [*]While I personally did not have performance problems, people I play co-op with did, so your mileage may vary.
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
    [*]There's a few spots where the AI makes weird choices, but hasn't ruined my experience.
    [*]A few bits of the UI could explain some things better, especially when it comes to Chaos Faction things.
    [*]The new additions to sieges are nice, but the AI does seem to struggle on the defensive.
    [*]Diplomacy feels "off" especially with Slaanesh. Being unable to vassalize an ally with their special means just makes it awkward.
[/list]

[h1]The Ugly[/h1]
[list]
    [*]While I have had no problems playing the game, people I play co-op with have had performance issues. Your mileage may vary.
[/list]

[h1]System Specs[/h1]
[list]
    [*]CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790K Processor @ 4.40GHz
    [*]CPU Cooler: Corsair H100i
    [*]GPU: GeForce GTX 970 G1 Gaming
    [*]Memory: Corsair Vengeance 32GB
    [*]OS: Windows 10 Pro
[/list]
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Gameplay Familiarity, Target Audience
