review_text:
Very disappointing. CA are clearly incapable of fixing the issues with the game. AI is the worst it's ever been for the franchise. The AI is literally not capable of pathing on maps. I skip every single siege battle and just use auto resolve, attacking or defending, because the experience of actually doing the battles is so miserable.

Melee units can't walk in a straight line to a target reliably. Introduce anything mega advanced like having to walk around a corner and they just crap themselves, idle where they are or choose a path to the target that involves circumventing the entire map. No joke, they walk literal kilometres in the wrong direction AWAY FROM THE SELECTED TARGET if you don't herd them. By herd, I mean select the unit, select the destination. Select the destination as fast as you can 200 times to try to get them to path to it instead of away form it.

 The ranged units will often simply not shoot, when they have clear los. I had an enemy general on a flying mount right in front of 10 units of archers. The archers just stand there, do nothing. I'm favouring single entity units simply because there able to navigate from a to b better. Factions that reply on ranged are basically just 2nd rate choices now. Skaven being a good exmaple.

They've tried patching AI, when they do, it typically get's worse, not better. They clearly have no clue how to manage the AI system or make improvements to it. I suspect the level of technical debt they have allowed to build up has put them in a situation where there simply incapable of making changes or fixing issues.

In the mean while, CA are happy to squat down over our dinner plates to release some "content" for us at twice the previous price and with less in it. When players complain, CA  threatens the community with dropping support for the game if they don't buy overpriced garbage.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, AI Performance

review_text:
I've changed my rating multiple times with the company that makes these games, "Creative Assemly." They do some really good work, but also have some very bad PR and QA when releasing updates and DLC. A lot of stuff breaks, and then they have to get downvoted to Hell in order for them to do anything about it. Unfortunately, this will probably continue.

However, I need to talk about the game. If you love Medieval Fantasy or want to just see armies clash in glorious fashion, the Warhammer trilogy is an excellent asking price. The problem is, you will not be able to play every faction. A lot of stuff is locked behind DLC. You can however, pick a faction you'd like to try, and then just purchase THAT DLC. It pays to get good with how a faction works and plays because they all basically have different mechanics. Just look through a faction and see if it makes you go "That looks cool" then give the DLC (if any) a purchase. They're all not that badly priced. It's badly priced if you want EVERY faction, which I've ended up collecting over the years. The problem is is that if you're completionist, you'll want everything. I've purchased every faction and still basically play two factions regularly: The Empire, and the Vampire Counts, and those factions are free with Warhammer 1. 

Warhammer 3 is excellent in that you can play Warhammer 1 and 2's gigantic world map for literally hundreds of hours. It is a fantastic blending of everything they've worked on over the last 10 years, and the scope and scale of everything is mind-bogglingly impressive. It's almost over-whelming. That's why I say, just start with 1 or 2 factions that interest you and learn how to play them, because you will be playing that faction for most of your game time. If you're wanting all faction DLC, wait for a sale, and go ham. I think the prices are a little over-priced, but mostly fair. Your enjoyment will be tested on whether you like really long campaigns with learning how to manage an army on a field. There is a lot to learn, but it's not overwhelming to the point where you won't know how to play. The game offers great in-game tutorials as you play, as well as offering a prologue to the main storyline of Warhammer 3 that teaches you everything you need to know about how to manage your towns, grow them, and how to grow and use your armies in battle. Each army type has a strength and weakness, and it's best to learn not to send horseman galloping into a field of spear infantrymen unless you want your horses to all die. Learning how each unit works is fascinating and helps you grow stronger. 

All in all, I recommend this game. It has repeatable patterns of CA releasing updates that break parts of the game here and there, but not to the point where you can't start the game and play. It's mostly broken mechanics and other monetary bullshit, that they only seem to fix when everyone mass down-votes them. That's why you'll see a "Mostly Positive" with an "Overwhelminlgy Negative" mixed in from time to time. But, if it's the only way to get them stablize the game each patch, then that's how it has to be. This game rocks.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability & Support, Consumer Value & Pricing Model, Gameplay & Content Accessibility

review_text: For someone who owns all possible content for this game(Yes even Shadows of Change) it got to say OK CA this has been the last straw from upping the price to ridiculous levels its one thing but to tell the comunity "support us or we will not further improve Total War warhammer with patches,fixes etc etc" is a total different level of scumbag holding the future of the IP hostage for your mistakes and refusing to accept that you made those mistakes and i do think i am not the only one who has or had this tought for a while but unless we will see some improvements and genuine effort i for one who has more than 1.5k hours into W1-W3 will no longer buy your "content rich dlc"a franchise that i adored and waited for so many years to see it grow to be sent into the trashcan by some jackasses or scumbags at the top of the company.

review_text:
I guess I am falling all the other reviews. This will (hopefully) be a great game, but for now its mhhhh. 
They have tried to mix it up from the previous two installments, with a new siege style. Effectively the longer a siege lasts the more points you get which you can spend on building more defences, this should make a siege into a collapsing bag, where you slowly pull troops back to a central defence. Unfortunately the defences take so long to build, that the siege is long over by the time they do any good. 
Others have detailed the horrid camapign, in a nut shell you need three terroitories and 2/3 armies. If you expand beyond that you really cant win as portals appear everywhere spawning corruption and chaos armies.  The first time you go into the chaos lands to complete the linear missions is fun, but this gets dry very quickly, as you rinse and repeat over and over. 
Then there are the armies (again, hopefully more to be added). There is chaos undivided, which are ok, but not as much fun as chaos in WH2, all the other chaos are worse versions of this, with limited rotas, either lacking average infantry or adequate cavalry, or artillery, the effort to give them a flavour just makes them feel hamstrung. 
Kislev are ok, playing like the empire, but Cathay are the only list to feel like they have any real new character. 
I am 88 hours in, have completed the campaigns with three factions, and done a world domination - the latter felt like a full time job, ...so dry...every battle feels the same, every region seems identical.... auto resolve after auto resolve... 
This game can be saved but needs expansions, so please don't encourage lazy development, wait till the price drops and the expansions are out.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Strategic Balance, Campaign Design

review_text:
I love this series clearly, I wouldn’t have 2,000+ hours if I didn’t. But it’s tiring watching the same cycle repeat: slow responses, late hotfixes, long silences, and then statements that come only once the damage is already done.

The recent AI freeze bug should’ve been caught and fixed faster. It’s not the end of the world by itself, but it’s a symptom of something deeper CA always seems to be reacting instead of anticipating.

I don’t expect perfection, just quicker awareness and communication. I want to feel like problems are being noticed before they explode into controversy.

Warhammer III is an incredible game underneath the chaos, and it deserves a better level of care and urgency.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Developer Communication, Long-term Support

review_text:
[h3] Update April 2024 [/h3]

I decided to change my recommendation to positive in view of recent news regarding layoffs at CA, the rampant rumors around Total War: Warhammer III being scaled down from what was originally planned, and lastly because the additions to Shadows of Change were pretty good. 

Despite the fact that multiplayer campaigns barely function, despite the random CTD's, units having seriously bad pathfinding around gates and ladders, Warriors of Chaos and Cathay tech not working properly, or that there are heroes with not enough skills to put their skill points into, I still love this game. A lot of that love lies in thanks to the modding community, but the love and work that [strike]CA[/strike] the Warhammer team have put into it is undeniable.

Finally, a message to SEGA. [b]Do not let this game die before it gets a chance to redeem itself[/b] The whole reason we're here is due to CA leadership being incompetent, out of touch, greedy [spoiler]dirt[/spoiler]bags
Punish them, not the game that makes money despite their best efforts to gun it down while it's laying the golden eggs.

[hr][/hr]
[h3] Update Feb 2024[/h3]

Since I posted this review, CA made a public statement "apologizing" (quotes because the wording of the apology was very corporate and didn't really make the point of owning up to mistakes) but also promising to be better. [b] In this vein, they cut the price of Total War: Pharaoh, refunded all owners, and promised to add content to Shadows of Change to match the asking price. [/b] This all happened in late December. 

They are currently coming out with a series of blog posts detailing the added units/lords/heroes in every race (at the time of writing this, only Cathay and Tzeentch are out) and the update is due next week. 

However, I will not be changing my recommendation yet, as this whole ordeal has been going on since the game was released. I'd like to have them be consistently good for a good long while before I can honestly recommend the game. Plus, it's still riddled with bugs.  
[hr][/hr]
[h3] Original Review in November [/h3]

I'm sorry, as many hours of entertainment this game, which I truly love, has given me, I cannot in good conscience recommend it. 

Unfortunately, Creative Assembly have been treating it as a money maker that will always make money no matter what, essentially abandoning it in the process. 

Their idea of "support" is to let a haggard, poor dlc team of, I would wager, less than twenty people to maintain, patch, AND produce content, while at the same time  increasing prices to absurd amounts for lesser quality content than for every other dlc ever. 

In the meantime, as the team is stretched super thin, glaring problems (which the community has addressed in mere days via mods) have been left in the game for months at a time. Imagine buying a faction dlc focused on a specific unit, and that faction being completely unable to recruit said unit FOR THREE ENTIRE MONTHS.

And to top things off, they came out with a statement as a response to community backlash for the latest price increase, basically saying "we want more money, buy the dlc or we drop support entirely" 

Tldr: CA have abandoned this game. QA is non-existent, major bugs are in the game for months on end, and CA came out with an ultimatum to buy the dlc at an absurd price or they'll drop support.
Review_Angles: Developer Support & Content Updates, Technical Performance & Bugs, Modding Community Value

review_text:
I’ve been playing Total War since the original Medieval Total War came out in 2002. That’s now over two decades of supporting this franchise, and Creative Assembly. That stops now.

CA has made some pretty bad missteps and mistakes in the past, with dodgy launches, buggy games, removing features, and flat out shovelware being spat out (looking at you, Thrones of Britannia). Despite this, the company also put out some amazing games during that time, and many people working there have shown they care about the games they make, and the community that supports them.

However, the current state of WH3, and the behaviour of certain executives at CA, has devolved to a state that is so appalling, it’s scarcely believable. WH3 has been a buggy, half finished mess since launch. The Realm of Chaos campaign is the flat out worst Total War campaign I’ve ever seen. Patches have been slow, barely fix any issues, and more often than not introduce a new suite of bugs to go alongside the old ones. Couple this with poor AI, factions with limited flavour or choice, and mechanics that are totally broken means the game cannot be recommended in the state it’s in.

Whilst this is disappointing, as WH2 became a truly brilliant experience after a while, and WH3 has the foundation to be another excellent game, the real kick in the teeth is the condescending and frankly insulting attitude CA are showing to their players. CA has basically hiked the price of DLC by 150%, whilst reducing the content included in the DLC, and failing to support the game appropriately. A certain executive then had the nerve to effectively threaten the playerbase with ending support for the game if they don’t buy it. 

But that’s the problem isn’t it CA, you aren’t supporting the game. You’re egregiously squeezing a loyal and dedicated community to prop up the development of a hero shooter, a genre that would’ve been new and exciting in 2014, whilst simultaneously sneering at the community that has kept you in business for 20 years. 

As a result, I’m out. Don’t buy this game. Don’t buy any DLC. Don’t support CA in any way anymore. If CA realise the error of their ways and actually change course, I’ll update this review. However, based on the complete contempt they seem to view their community with, it’s probably more likely that pigs will fly. Ironically, flying pigs would be a more developed and thought out unit than most of the ones they include in their DLC.
Review_Angles: Historical Loyalty, Technical Stability, Corporate Behavior

review_text:
I've played Warhammer 1, 2 and 3. First time leaving a review. I've played lots of Warhammer 2, fair bit of 3 as well. Scope and concepts? Amazing. Super cool ideas. And I enjoyed 2 a lot after potion of speed update, which made turn times playable, among other things. But they left the game broken in it's final patch (ambush AI completely broken), and were okay leaving it like that. It just left a sour taste in the mouth after so much fun with a great game.

Then Warhammer 3 launches, game broken and unfinished. Some fixes, more breaks, some fixes, more breaks. Siege pathfinding just absolutely broken, tower minigames, AI AFKing on world map, they don't launch sieges and just stand around forever waiting to attack. Cathay was marketed on "defending the bastion", but armies never launch the attack, and if they do, they can still be auto resolved on very hard (aka, auto resolve still has serious issues, eg dwarves vs norsca and slaneesh auto resolve diff). Just... Warhammer 2, from potion of speed update up to before the final patch which broke it, was great. Not perfect, but fun, lots of new content, game worked, issues were fixed within reasonable time frames? Warhammer 3? Core issues like AI just afking on map and sieges being just...... pathfinding and LOS drives me nuts, barriers popping up out of nowhere to make it worse. Cant even compensate by destroying walls properly, as it always leaves invulnerable sections. There's so much potential in the game, it's so frustrating to see it squandered over just, the game being broken and not working as intended. Let alone the insane powercreep (cough skulltaker, cough) which is just ridiculous levels of broken that all you can do is laugh really.

I'd just like to see the game series that I've spent so much time in actually be fixed and playable, not a buggy mess, and this is the only way I can really express that. I haven't played in months because among other things in life being busy, the bugs, pathfinding/LOS issues and sieges general design just drives me up the wall after a while, along with no challenge cause the AI just AFKs and watches me play solitaire. Hopefully you can turn the game around CA, rather than giving it the Three Kingdoms treatment, or leaving it broken like Warhammer 2. Thanks for reading.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, Developer Accountability

Lets not talk about how bad is pricing sometimes here
TWW3 is a great game itself with a giant potential for further improvements. That's one of the biggest Warhammer based video game, medieval fantasy based video game I would say which does have both interesting & pretty big global map as well as battles done in interesting manner. 
It's never a talk that this game is 10/10 and has everything being done ideal. It tries, and it actually **tries well**. I've spent so far near 300 hours playing it, and I enjoy playing it evenings after a job, I enjoy playing it together with friends of my. 
It's just a **great potential product** which you can already taste much. Though, aiming my positive review still for further improvements.  
Multiplayer experience sometimes sucks with having of issues and crashes just without a reason ( and proper tell of a reason ), bit it's still fun and enjoyable to play.**Wish CA would take actual care of content and support**. This ain't a game which we as a customers should lose, but it's still also a game company which develops it **should take care of**.

review_text:
Played it in ver 6.2 

This is has an extensive Workshop support but some MOD only work in certain versions of the game.
Beware that you also need to be careful in the MOD load order and enable them on the game launcher.

I only play it on 2 campains:

-The Lost God (an amazing prologe, if you remember to close the 'tuturial message' before doing what you are being told to do)

-The Realm of Chaos (Amazing lore but the passing is a bit too slow if you are trying to save Ursun. 
I won the campain via comple map dominance before the 2nd portal to the 'realms of chaos' pop up)

To be honest, the tutorial campain for me was better than the actual game campain.
It felt far more immersive Yuri Journey than 'who ever faction you want to play' but with the same story.

Mods realy help me to complete the campain and make Boris a Barbarian from Skyrim with an army of Snow Dragons and Cryo Phoenix (Similar to Anivia from Freljord)
Also used a mod to even the odds when fighting in weird climates, diseases and lack of qualified personel to defend a barren wasteland.

The DLC is only if you want a 2nd playthrough, to be honest it isn't mandatory.
Try the 'Realms of Chaos' campain before going into 'Inmortal Empires', the last campain is just a bigger map and to be honest feels more empty than 'Realms of Chaos'

Maybe if they had made their campains a bit more like the tutorial or like those from Warcraft 3.
They could have just made fewer races and just focus on those.

I know by doing that, they wouldn't be able to monetize new factions as easy as they do with their new DLCs
Warhammer 'Old World' Lore is rich and it is a shame they weren't able to make a more interesting 'main story'.

Like it or hate it, 
This game is a good staring point for those who want to know what is Warhammer and not just 40k.

I was listening a great lore channel while playing the campain:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JEQtsOpCAIE&list=PLxbR0SRy9VpBWgkbLqmRGysJxvZLoEft3&index=26

This game isn't for everyone.
Side with who ever you like the most and don't regret your choice.
Review_Angles: Modding & Technical, Narrative & Immersion, Gameplay Pacing

review_text:
Overall another amazing Warhammer title. Can look toward my Warhammer 2 review for more detail, as this is obviously a sequel to such. Greatly enjoy the vastly improved visuals, map, and reworked or newer factions added along with the detailed game modes and newer systems implemented regarding them. BUT there are SOME DRAWBACKS as well. Main drawbacks being the limited playable factions until mortal empires is released, bugs and overall balancing issues, and larger optimization and performance issues than previous titles needing attention / editing  for proper gameplay for most players. Overall, i'd say this is another fantastic release, BUT, i'd RECOMMEND WAITING UNTIL A PRICEDROP / OPTIMIZATION PATCH / MORTAL EMPIRE RELEASE. The overall lack of playable factions as well as the extremely rough optimization currently and balancing issues definitely need to be addressed. Once mortal empires drops, the playable faction list will be much larger, so i'd withhold until then. A solid 7 or 8 /10 until optimization or mortal empires, which would likely boost it up to an absolute 10/10 masterpiece. All players being able to perform their turn at once is also a GODSENT feature in regards to time consumption playing multiplayer.

>monke
WHEN MORTAL EMPIRE? ? ?

review_text: Nearly 3,000 hours into WH3, 20+ years of playing Total War (started when I was 7) and now I haven't played a Total War game consistently for nearly a month. The constant game breaking bugs on "newer" titles - yes newer is subjective, just can't take it anymore. If this was something that truly has "been in the game a lot longer than foreseen" then get better game testers. Not to mention the lack attention these bugs seem to get. review_text:
Update: 9/11/2023

CA doesn't deserve your money. They threaten to kill their biggest cash cow if the community doesn't buy their newest dlc at extortionate price increase? 

You mean just like you killed 3 kingdoms CA? 

F*** you guys, how F****** dare you? Its not like you have a massive community to begin with, and your small community has been nothing but loyal, building you up for decades, and then you threaten us with this shit? 

You don't deserve the license, you don't deserve any of us business at all, until you issue an apology. 


The year is 2016. Warhammer Fantasy has been blown up and replaced by Age of Sigmar to mixed reviews. The Warhammer you know and love is well and truly gone. You hear that there's a new Total War game coming out based on the franchise. 

Oh boy, another game getting the warhammer license. Time to flip the coin and see if it will be good or bad. 

Turns out its pretty ground breaking. Turns out they plan to make this a trilogy. 

Turns out, they plan to combine all 3 into one mega game. 

yea, okay. 

The year is 2022. Immortal Empires is out. One of the most ambitious gaming projects in not just strategy games, but games as a medium in the last 20 years, has just entered its final stage. 

Games Workshop currently sees unprecedented growth as a company, and warhammer is back on the big stage. 

Does the game have bugs? can it be a bit janky at times? Of course, its a MASSIVE game.

its a fun as shit to play? 

you bet your little ass. 

Blood for the blood god. Skulls for the Skull Throne. Rejoice and Revel in the destruction of the realm, over and over again.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Company Ethics, Franchise Legacy

review_text:
While I have gotten alot of time out of twwh3 and spent an unhealthy amount of money following the trilogy and its insane amount of DLC through to the modern day. I cannot in good conscious recommend the game in its current state. 

This is due not to balance, not to the core gameplay, not to the visuals, but to the sheer volume of technical debt this game is in, a degree in which even Stellaris has a run for its money in just how deeply broken it is. 

Its been years and yet the game still runs horribly, loading times are slow even with a multi-gigabyte per second SSD and on an old disc drive you might as well go out to lunch every time you enter or exit a battle. Slowing the game to a crawl.

Once you are ingame, your fps will crater if your gpu isnt on the high end of midline unless you dumpster your settings, the game paradoxically running better on higher unit sizes, atleast on my gpu, and other such estranged issues and inexplicable lag that will haunt you even when the game is working properly.

Which it wont be. The fire at will bug still occurs semi frequently, a bug that requires you to manually target every single ranged unit in your army, in the campaign the A.I cheats frequently and bugs out immensely even more often. From A.I building completely inexplicable armies of 6 different types of infantry, casting spells on completely empty open terrain, standing around hopelessly in battles it started, or just breaking entirely. As can be seen with the lizardmen and tomb kings major factions which currently just idle in their capitols until destroyed. 

If you want to run a DLC business model, I'll buy it as the least scummy option to run a game indefinitely. But ultimately, the game needs to FUNCTION PROPERLY for that dlc to be worth buying. 

If the game is unplayable, or just downright unfun, then you will never get your moneys worth, even if you dont mind the DLC. And that is the state of the game right now. All the completely unnecessary friction makes me stop and question if I even want to play the game between each and every turn. And increasingly the answer is no.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Performance & Optimization, Long-term Support & Technical Debt

review_text:
Great concept, seeing Warhammer units and locals in action had me very excited.  
But even from release things have been consistently half-arsed and bareboned. Then DLC later kept increasing in cost while SIMULTANEOUSLY decreasing in value.  The latest DLC has less units, with low effort detail (Tzaangors just have blue horns) and less animations (the War Drum has none).   
This could maybe be forgiven if there was attention elsewhere, but the base game has had known bugs for months (Nakai still cant recruit Kroxigors), and promised reworks that was supposed to come out the same time as the DLC (like sieges) have had no mention.  

Sadly this game, despite its potential, is becoming less and less worth what you're paying for
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Content Quality, Technical Support

review_text:
It's the best large-scale strategy I've ever played (only if you're playing solo), multiplayer has a big issues like desync. If you play with friends in multiplayer campaign you'll encountered with issues like: 
1. In some turn game just freezing and after few seconds you are thrown out of it, without any notification (this happens even not in the battle, just in global map).
2. No matter where you are in middle of the battle or in global map sometimes you can see desync with your friends by the following notification "Waiting for a player ..." and you think "oh it takes few seconds and after that game will resume". I said you that we have 3 ways what will happen: 
1) game MAYBE will resume; 
2) game can freeze with the same notification "Waiting for a player ..." in everyone and you can do nothing, the only way to solve it is press ALT+F4; 
3) last but not least, one of your friends will throw out from the game without any notification, but you can think that your friend reconnect to the session, I say you NO. You need to quit to main menu and rehost the campaign.

I don't know when these issues started, but as I see on the forums, players have been complaining about this for at least 9 months.

Conclusion:
Game is the best if you are fan large-scale strategies, but only for solo game, multiplayer is broken, it's impossible to play. I "HOPE" developers will fix this.

(Note: I have not played PvP modes, all words above from the experience of playing with friends in multiplayer campaign)
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Multiplayer Experience, Solo Gameplay Quality

review_text:
It's an excellent game. People sometimes review it poorly because they don't agree with CA's actions. If you look at it on its own merits though, the gameplay, unit variety, and scope is immense and the amount of content is truly unparalleled. I've had a lot of fun with it, and this is coming from a fan who prefers historical games. Yes there are bugs and lingering issues in the engine like the gate bug, and annoying features like butt ladders, and the company making the game have made questionable decisions, including the abstraction of detail many players like myself miss from previous years. Overall though, Warhammer 3 has received many quality of life improvements that make going back to the older games a bit painful - stat breakdowns, replenishment, unique faction playstyles and campaign mechanics. 

Ultimately, playing this game is fun, which is a very good reason to play it.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Quality, Developer Reputation Impact, Comparative Historical Context

review_text:
The game is solid and I like playing it, the company that manages it showed very low amounts of respect for it in the past with The Shadows of Change DLC - which was announced at a price so high that the playerbase got mad, the official statement by CA posed a not-so-veiled threat that if it didn't do well they might drop development on the game:
"There’s no good time to increase prices, and we have not taken this step lightly. However, this is the business reality of supporting WARHAMMER III and ensuring we’re able to offer the years of extra content that are currently planned."

Since then they seem to be dedicating more attention to the game with frequent updates and are working on improving the aforementioned DLC, we'll see if it sticks in the future.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Company Relationship, Post-Launch Support

review_text:
I’ve loved the Total War series for years and spent hundreds of hours in Warhammer 1 & 2  but Warhammer 3 is an absolute mess in its current state. After years on the market, the game is still plagued with bugs, and every major update seems to break something else. Since patch 6.3, the AI barely recruits armies at all, making entire campaigns feel pointless and empty.

Instead of focusing on fixing the core game, Creative Assembly keeps pushing overpriced DLC with questionable value. Many DLCs release in a broken state and need fixes later.

On top of that, if you want to experience the game fully, you’re basically forced to own Warhammer 1 and 2 and their DLCs on top of paying full price for Warhammer 3 itself. That’s a ridiculous amount of money for a single game experience.

To make matters worse, I currently own 7 out of 28 DLCs available for this game, and Steam tells me the rest would cost me €319.22. Let me repeat: this is supposed to be a full-price title, yet playing it in its entirety costs far more than any AAA release on the market.

I want to enjoy this series, but right now it feels more like an overpriced Game you have to assemble piece by piece to get the Full experience. It’s frustrating, disappointing, and simply not worth it.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Consumer Value, Monetization Model

"Hi everyone. I’m **Rob Bartholomew**, Chief Product Officer here at Creative Assembly.

To get right into it: our costs are up. Unfortunately, that means that prices have to rise. We know any increase is going to be tough, which is why our prices have remained fairly stable over the past few years. The downside is that any increase today is going to be more noticeable.

review_text:
Pretty good bang for your buck, though there are a few large problems that don't look like they're going to be patched any time soon. 

-Diplomacy and general AI is fairly bad, even on harder difficulties. A lot of this is due to weighted values not being arranged correctly, a lot of it is down to the core behaviors being nonsensical. 
-Warhammer 1 factions still don't feel great to play. They've gotten a fair few overhauls but they could probably use a building rework, more units, better campaign mechanics, etc. Their economies also feel generally weaker than factions that came later. I would honestly say that WH2 factions have the opposite problem, where they have a slightly stronger economy (and I would argue stronger factions/units overall). If faction balance bothers you at all then this is something to consider.
-Steamrolling is still an issue and the systems implemented to slow it are uninteresting or unfun. 
-The process of actually transitioning to the late game can feel quite slow and you'll often feel like your campaign is basically done by the time you start getting armies of high-tier units. The process of retrofitting armies with these units is also pretty annoying.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Balance, AI Performance

review_text:
Amended review (was positive, now negative until fixed).

I love Warhammer and I’ve poured an embarrassing number of hours into WH3 (3 different accounts between the mrs and me), but at ~9 years into this trilogy and after more DLCs/patches than I can count, the game has no business being this buggy and unfinished. 

The current cycle pushed me over the edge. Campaign AI is all over the place, especially after 6.3, (major factions sitting idle, weird passivity, protectionist blob behavior), battles still cough up pathing and targeting nonsense (particularly sieges), and every patch feels like two steps forward, one faceplant back. I shouldn’t have to mod basic sanity back into a flagship strategy title this far in. 

Even the Kislev re-work (which while is great from a 'we're willing to listen to the community' angle,  is sorely lacking the in # of units for the faction - seriously - do a comparison between Kislev and other factions (IMHO units like the things and the woods and Incarnate Elemental only make sense for Ostankya) What Kislev needs is 1 more (melee) hero, 3-5 more units incl/ an additional artillery option (Ice Guard Bear Riders and/or Ice Guard Sleds anyone?) and 3-4 more RoRs. Considering the amazing work of the modding community - half of your work is already done for you CA... Just saying.

But what really stings is the business/meta layer. The DLC bloat/treadmill means “complete” costs a fortune, yet QA/regression keeps slipping. And the community side feels… corporate. Partner programs, managed access, and PR tone-policing have gotten so heavy that creators who call out company behavior (not just unit balance) get sidelined. You can see the ripple effect in the LegendofTotalWar drama and others: instead of channeling community pressure into faster, cleaner fixes, we spiral into tribalism while the game remains broken for months.

I’m not asking for miracles. I’m asking for:

-Stability-first patches (lock the AI before selling anything new).
-Transparent QA (what broke, why, when it’ll be fixed).
-Reasonable DLC cadence/pricing aligned with actual quality delivered.
-Less managed messaging, more accountability with creators and players.

Flip those switches and I’ll happily flip this back to positive. Until then, it’s hard to recommend a game I adore that keeps tripping over the same rakes.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, Development Progress

review_text:
I was thrown out before the battle with the main demon three times, and a few times during big battles (which can happen at different times).

It looks like a DLC, not a new game, but it has a list of updates, a new map, and a price like a DLC, so it is okay. I see a lot of static elements, and I don’t like it—the game's progress is halted, making it boring for me. There are many UX problems. I hate using the map and managing the army sometimes. Also, I miss good information about the army; it causes chaos.

However, it is a unique game, and sometimes I want to play something like this. We have the ability to wage war with a big army, and I am happy to have this opportunity.

But in the Warhammer series, we don’t have 3D models of the army—the biggest problem for me when playing a big strategy game.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Content Value, User Experience

review_text:
Right now it's "pretty good." So far I haven't run into any major performance issues like some other people. I'm at least getting 60fps in battles and 70-80 on the map, with all settings maxed. I could no doubt improve it by dropping some things down, but it's good enough for me. (high end PC, 3080, 5800X). Like most people, I'm not a huge fan of the all-red UI, but the game play is pretty much exactly what I was looking forward to. Like TWW2, I will probably dabble in this until the Mortal Empires campaign arrives, and then play the **** out of it. It was still worth pre-ordering just for the ogres. The specifically aligned chaos gods are a bit lacking compared to undivided, humans, and ogres.

I will add that I also had a mouse alignment problem when it started in 1080p and I upped it to 1440p, but it went away after quitting to desktop and restarting, and never came back.

Like TWW 1 and 2, I am sure this will receive loads of balance, improvements, and DLCs as time goes by. If your a fan of the series it might be worth picking up now, but it will definitely be worth it once the sandbox campaign comes out. 

I could change my review for better or worse as I play more, but thought I would at least throw out my first impressions, since they've been mostly positive, unlike a lot of people.
Review_Angles: Technical Performance, User Interface Design, Gameplay Content

review_text:
EDIT 3: It's fucked again... 

EDIT 2: We good now 

The game is great, don't get me wrong. But $25 FUCKING DOLLARS FOR A DLC? 

EDIT: I wanted to expand a bit more regarding the pricing. I love the game, I really do. I wish I could have more time to play it religiously. Unfortunately, DLC price policy is fucking ridiculous. Rubbing salt to the wound, each and every time they are adding less and less and less content with each stupidly priced package. And it seems they don't notice the amount of bugs that are in the game. Have you seen the Kroxigors? Can you recruit them with Nakai without a mod? Nope.

When Forge of the Chaos Dwarves was released, I though to myself: "Neat, I love the faction. I'll buy it. It doesn't make sense the high price for the content, but I want to see for myself how this is." And of course, I bought it. Some of you might say that was a stupid move. Yes, absolutely it was. But I'm enjoying the Chaos Dwarves as much as I can.

Then Shadows of Change got announced and it mentioned some additional stuff for Cathay with I really like the faction as well. They could use a buff here and there but still, I like it. 

However, everything came crashing down like the fucking Hindenburg in 1937 when the content was announced, and it fucked everything up after they announced AGAIN that for $25  you will get:

1) 3 FUCKING LEGENDARY LORDS
2) 12 FUCKING UNITS
3) 9 NEW REGIMENTS OF RENOWN

THAT SMALL LITTLE PIECE OF SHIT CONTENT FOR $25... 

But it gets worse, not only they think we are fucking stupid enough to believe the horseshit they released as a statement. Specially this part: 

"To get right into it: our costs are up. Unfortunately, that means that prices have to rise. We know any increase is going to be tough, which is why our prices have remained fairly stable over the past few years. The downside is that any increase today is going to be more noticeable."

And sure, how do you want to keep being stable and have money if you keep doing stupid stuff? Thrones of Britannia... Binned since people didn't like it. Pharaoh, I can positively assure you it will be binned as well since it's trying to be sold as a Bronze Age game, which is not completely true. I guarantee, if Pharaoh doesn't meet the standards they set, it will end up as Britannia. Which is sad. Thrones of Britannia setting and sieges are top notch, it's a shame the rest of the game doesn't come up to that level.

Sorry for the long text and honestly I don't care anymore about this. I will continue playing it, but I will wait maybe until 2029 when the upcoming DLCs are on a very low price for me to buy them. 

How about you please listen to the community, be open for feedback and not act like a bunch of spoiled brats that get offended if somebody doesn't praise their gold-covered piece of crap served on the plate. 

Be better, be creative. Give us Medieval 3, Empire 2, Shogun 3. Hell, get the viking era correctly and I assure you, people will start having hope for you again. And please for the love of god, can we get naval combat again? That thing is awesome and new games are lacking naval combat even if the setting actually has famous naval battles.

 At the moment, you guys are not being managed correctly and that has to change. Game Development is hard, I know that for a fact since I already participated in a couple of very small projects, but raking the price from $15 to $25 for less content? Come on, have some common sense...
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Content Quantity

Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Developer Reputation

review_text:
Here is the deal,

I have played every single TW and dealt with some letdowns from CA such as the rome 2 launch, Attila’s optimization issues, the abandonment of three Kingdoms.

I have seen some great stuff from CA as well like shogun 2, Imperator Augustus update and Warhammer 2.

I want this game to be better than all the above but some serious changes need to happen.

I have never disliked a game so much that I would put as much effort into a review like I have today. I normally post one word reviews and carry on because I have better things to do with my time. This has been the worst experience I’ve had with a developer ever.

Warhammer 3 has some serious campaign, pricing and lack of fun issues.

The single player campaign is a mess. I’ve completed two campaigns so far, kislev and daniels. I have never been so frustrated by the AI to consider mods but I’m going to install some for my third. For example 15 turns into a normal game and skovald attacks me from 30 miles away with a gold chevroned doom stack of great sword blood letters. Even if my forces could oppose him he would run around my army sacking and razing undefended settlements just like in Warhammer 1. In addition AI cheating is so brutal it takes the fun out of the game. Aggression and war declaration has been taken up to 11 to the point where you can’t afford a big enough army to defend against all the swarming factions or progress in a meaningful way. I understand that CA is updating anti player bias in 4.0 but the fact that this is being addressed two years later is just plain unacceptable. Before the CA simps or employees say “just lower the difficulty” all I have to say is that that this is not in line with Warhammer 1 & 2. I know what the difficulty level is in the total war genre and this is not normal. 

The best TW comparison I can come up with is it’s like realm divide gets happens on turn 5-6 in most campaigns.

Another gripe was partially mentioned above if I do have the upper hand the AI runs away from every engagement. My forces cannot keep up and the sacking and razing continues.

If you actually convince another ai faction to ally with you then congrats! They will drag you into more wars and then proceed to not lend assistance or build any army of their own. Again this is the anti player bias at work.

How did this happen? Warhammer 2 was the template you needed to stick with! You had a grand slam that just needed to be copy pasta’d and you ****** it up.

 I’m not going to explain what is going on with pricing because other reviews have covered it off. What I will say is Rob Barltholomew should be fired. Not because of the price increase but because of the way he treated CA’s customers. I found his response to the dlc complaints completely out of touch and condescending. I took the time to look up the parent companies ( sega-sami holdings ) operating expenses from 2022 and 2023 as it’s publicly traded. Sega's operating expenses were up like 20% year over year. 

So don’t **** on my back and tell me it’s a shower Rob! explain to me how this adds up? 

The others who complained over this pricing are correct it’s just strait up greed. I imagine I’m like most other folks that would happily pay 20% even 25% more because I generally like CA’s work but 150% justified by a lie is just infuriating. 


Here’s what’s I think players can do to improve Warhammer 3.

Pray superman sees this review so he can shame creative assembly into fixing this mess. He tried to fix the witcher he will try and fix this.

don’t buy the dlc and don’t pre order anything from any video game developer ever again 

Voice your concerns and call out CA on forums, Reddit, YouTube or pornhub

Reach out to stock analysts who cover Sega Sami holdings. Ask them if they know that a subsidiary of sega is having a bud light moment?

Ask YouTubers to not shill for these clowns. Let them know that their careers are dead if CA stops making these games. If they continue on this path the series will be wrecked before this game is through its cycle.

Don’t accept being gaslighted by people calling this “review bombing” If a customer is upset over a product it’s for a good reason. 

Ask for a developer response on the CA forums from someone who has two brain cells to rub together ( not that rodeo clown Rob ).

If CA does the right thing and fixes this mess of a game thank them and ask them not to screw another one up.
Reach out to the games workshop tell them you feel ripped off and that CA won’t help.

File BBB complaints against sega / CA.

Ask for a better customer experience. Amazon and Costco ask hardly any questions and will work with you to get refunded if something is not right. Amazon even charge backs the vendor. All the greats would never treat customers like this. If sega wants to be a big dog they need to start acting like one.


Good luck to all voicing their opinions and trying to improve this game! I hope someone from creative assembly or sega or whatever gets it together and makes this better than Warhammer 2.

review_text:
Perhaps the best installment of the Total War Franchise. Having played every installment of Total War, I can safely say that Warhammer III is one of the most gorgeous games they have made. The map has been lovingly designed to honor the source material. You won't get bored looking at the domains of each Chaos Realm. The battles are visually stimulating and enjoyable despite the continued decline in battle quality. This Total War continues the disappointing trend of moving away from the importance of tactics and formations and emphasizes the stats of blobs smashing into each other. Gone are the days of holding key choke points with tight formations of spear-walls or soaking up missile damage with defensive shield-walls. Battles are now a numbers games that are full of cheese. 

The victory mechanic is less annoying than Warhammer II's Vortex campaign. You no longer have to race to gather specific resources to reach a phase in your victory. You now win by going on expeditions into the Chaos Wastes through time-sensitive portals. The portals only open up every so often, so it can become rather annoying to be constantly waiting for a portal to open so that you can complete the campaign.

All in all, the game is well made and fun to play. A must-buy for Total War and Warhammer fans alike.
Review_Angles: Visual & Artistic Quality, Gameplay Mechanics, Franchise Evolution

review_text:
I'm going to be honest with you guys.
Total War: Warhammer is a great game! But it does have its downsides.
Not playwise, but because of the Dlcs. The base game on its own gives the player many races to play, and these races are pretty cool on their own. But having to buy some Dlcs just to be able to get maybe 1-2 more heroes into a race and 2-4 more units isn't really that fun. I've probably spent about 100€ or more just for the Dlcs I have, and I don't even have them all. 
Don't get me wrong, some dlcs are just amazing and worth the Money. Others are not.
I still think it's a great game. Being able to have massive Battles with Fantasy races where you can control your own troops makes a lot of time pass quickly and with joy.    

In conclusion: If you like strategic games in a fantasy setting, and you are willing to pay a couple bucks more than your usual game (not recommended if you are completely new, just use the free races). It might be the perfect long term game for you. 

ps. explosions are very fun :D

review_text:
With games, I often have "phases" of playing them which last for a week up to a month at a time. Sometimes, a game's longevity will only consist of one or two phases, while others last a few more. Total War: Warhammer is one of the latter. Perhaps even beyond that, as I have been playing this game consistently for well over 2 months now. For me, that says something.

I figured I'd have to leave a review when Creative Assembly made Immortal Empires available to everyone who owns the third game. Since I already had Immortal Empires, this decision had no bearing on me in terms of actual gameplay. However, this does tell me that the developers really do care about the community. Immortal Empires is an excellent experience and I believe, the definitive way to experience these games. Seeing all of the races & factions from every game come together on one map makes the experience feel complete. Each race is completely different in terms of style, roster and gameplay, allowing for countless hours to be spent on each one. They're all incredibly fun and there's a faction out there for everyone. Do you want to pummel the enemy with artillery and make them come to you? Try the Dwarfs. Do you want to swarm the enemy with mass numbers? Try Skaven. Or maybe, you'd like a more balanced roster allowing for a flexible playstyle- Empire.

Something that I don't often see mentioned, and one of my favourite aspects of the game, is the amount of detail around the Warhammer lore put into this game. Descriptions of units, items and buildings are all interesting and varied. Having not read any of the books or played the tabletop game, I find this all very engaging, helping me to keep immersed in the experience. The unit card art, soundtrack, and dozens upon dozens of maps all help to further accentuate this feeling.

All in all, Total War: Warhammer 3 is an excellent game. The main downside to me is the amount of money that needs to go into these games if you wish to unlock more races. Aside from that, blink and the hours trickle away...
Review_Angles: Game Longevity, Developer Support, Gameplay Experience

review_text: Absolute masterpiece. I clocked over 1k hours in Warhammer 2, and now almost 2k in Warhammer 3. We love the Vortex campaign, it's really nice having the extra option of gameplay. This game is truly endless, of course I have my favourite races to play, but it's always a completely different experience depending on who you play. It took me until approximately 2.5k hours of gameplay to finally master my first ratmen faction, and if I want a more chill and leisurely play, I can switch it up and play High Elves. My favourites are Greenskins of course, each of their factions are so unique because of the dynamics of the faction Lords and their affects. I have a spot dedicated in my heart for Grimgor obviously, but recently been practising some of the more difficult factions because I need a bit of a challenge (avoiding going to a higher difficulty until I run out of other options lmao). I honestly never shut up about this game, it's my favourite game hands down, of all time.

review_text:
Incredibly fun but buggy game suffering from incompetent management (not to mention arrogant and complacent).

If you don't leave this game in a great state at the end of its lifecycle, forget about players buying whatever bug-infested low-effort trash you come peddling next.

The company has a history of bugged releases and abruptly abandoning projects. Most recently, they think it's okay to leave the game majorly bugged for months (breaking AI for entire factions and continents).

Ranged units often don't fire at targets, cavalry and monsters are unable to effectively kill routing units, gate bugs out and becomes indestructible in offensive siege battles, certain factions on campaign map are idle and unable to recruit units, battle audio sometimes bugs out and stops playing, and many many such issues that have not been fixed for LITERAL YEARS and likely never will be! UNACCEPTABLE!

Also, it's been almost a full year since ANY major content update. Ironically TWW2's lifecycle and dlc model was great, with frequent and high quality releases. With TWW3 they made each dlc 1.5x bigger but it take 2-3x the time for them to release it. They changed what wasn't broken likely all to sneakily justify higher prices. It would be much better to go back to TWW2's model of 2 lord packs vs 3 lords in current game if it results in more frequent updates and releases, or even a single lord pack as long as the quality is there and updates are more frequent! It should also be much easier for them to QA smaller but more frequent updates.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Company Trust & Management, Gameplay Functionality

review_text:
So far I only played with Cathay and some Slaneesh. While there are a few things about the game that annoy the hell out of me(like Confederation and Vassals), there are huge improvements to gameplay in other areas like minor settlement battles, QoL changes etc. 

Game is just fine except for the performance issues and some bugs/glitches/oversights(such as supply lines bug). It'll eventually get better and most of the gamebreaking problems will be adressed. Keep in mind that Warhammer II wasnt that good a game either on release. It only got better after years of patching and fleshing out with DLCs. Surely they're planning to do the same here. 

However, if the performance loss is due to some sort of DRM like Denuvo then CA needs to realize that what they're doing doesnt hurt the people who pirate the game. It hurts the people who legitimately paid for it. My specs are about the reccomended level, I used to play TWWH2 with 60-70 fps on mid-high graphics and ultra unit scale but here its more like 40-50 with dips to 20-30s.  Only times I've experienced that in TWWH2 were like 4 armies of skelly boys blobbing up sort of situations. Until preformance issues are adressed this review stays a big fat no.


EDIT AFTER A YEAR: While some performance issues are still there, and game could look SO MUCH better just by giving the TAA some love and preventing motion blur, at least it feels stable around 60 fps with high graphics.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Mechanics, Long-term Development

review_text:
This game is extremely fun and improves on a lot of key systems from the previous title at the expense of some truly baffling design decisions and bad performance optimization. While it is a definite buy if you're a fan of series, even in it's current state, this game will likely greatly improve over it's lifetime as immortal empires gets implemented, dlc comes out, and bugs get ironed out.

Factions:
Most of the new factions are excellent. Their rosters are varied, campaign/battle mechanics unique, and their overall presentation is spectacular. I particularly enjoyed playing Ogre Kingdoms and Kislev, the latter with which I am currently close to winning the campaign with. Both these factions are also a great showcase of the overall evolution of the Warhammer 2 formula, though they are diametrically opposed to each other in play style, both on campaign and battle. Kislev plays the best when building tall (not expanding too fast and building up their forces/settlements). Their faction mechanics of the Ice Court, Attomans, and Invocations of the Motherland facilitate this perfectly. The Ogres are best when playing wide, as their settlements cant go past tier 3. This forces you to rely on their Ogre Camp mechanic, which is a super novel addition that fits the character of the ogres and allows for completely unique gameplay. Khorne and Cathay also are very fun to play, though at the time of this review I'm less experienced with them, as I opted to play a couple longer campaigns to get an overall feel of how this game plays in the mid/later stages, as this is likely where players will spend most of their time. 

Campaign:
I prefer Realm of Chaos in TW:W3 to the Vortex in TW:W2. I know its not a high bar to pass, but I seem to be in the minority on this issue. Pretty much every realm except Khorne and possibly Slanesh (though this is only because the temptations offered are actually tempting) is a gigantic slog to get through and distract you from your plans in the mortal realm. I don't really have to much to say about it as most of your time will be spent playing as if the chaos realms didn't exist. All I can say is that when immortal empires comes out, just as in Warhammer 2 and mortal empires, I will pretty much be playing that exclusively. I do think the teleportation mechanic of the rifts is actually very fun though. 

Edit: I take this back. I have no intention of touching realms of chaos ever again, and vortex may have actually been less aggravating. Thankfully immortal empires is not longer locked behind a massive paywall for new players. Overall, immortal empires is a direct improvement to Warhammer 2's mortal empires in pretty much every way.

Battle:
If you've played TW:W2, then you know whats going on. Unit design in awesome, sound design in excellent (the battle music is a GIGANTIC improvement over 2), and your overall level of control feels about the same as the previous title. Magic, although still powerful, has to be used more sparingly due to a overhaul of the winds of magic system, a change I don't welcome. Unit animations seem to have taken a bit of side-grade as well, as although overall fighting animations have improved, there are far less cool unique interactions between fighting units and characters. 

Edit: unit pathing has gotten weirder, but its still pretty decent.

Sieges:
I'm mixed on these. I'm a little disappointed that they aren't what the devs promised, but they are still more fun than in the previous game, especially when it comes to minor settlements. Taking walled cities is a lot tough too, requiring a significant force if you want to forgo tedious cheese. Mostly, I like that settlements have better garrisons and defensible positions, allowing significantly less babysitting when enemy forces decide to pay you a visit. 

Performance:
Yikes. I have a 1080ti, a 8700k, 32gb of ram and am running the game at 3440x1440. When I invoke the motherland in Kislev I get <30 fps on the campaign map. Otherwise, I get about 35-45. This is bad, especially considering this isn't leaps beyond the visual fidelity of Warhammer 2. In battle, my FPS is actually pretty good, staying above 60 for the most part. Since the fps is perfectly adequate where in counts, I still find this performance acceptable. CA has stated that performance/stability will a priority in the coming patches, so we will see if this improves. 

Edit: this has been fixed for the most part.

Misc pro/con:
+ MASSIVE diplomacy rework. Everything about the old system has pretty much been gutted and a sleek "quick deal" option has been added to help you find quickly filter factions to politic with. Military alliances and defensive alliances are now a boon to your campaign and not a detriment, as allied factions won't drag you into stupid wars as often and provide tangible benefits such as outposts (these allow you to recruit units of friendly factions!) and far improved war coordination options. Region trading has also FINALLY been added. 
+ Character screen improvement. Its a lot easier to manage your characters' equipment and followers. 
+ Lords+heroes in armies now level from damage dealt/kills inflicted in battle. This is an excellent change, as the more difficult the battle, the more XP you get. This remedies a big issue with the previous stemming from how slow characters leveled up (usually once per battle, no matter how significant it was). In this game, I've earned five levels with a general once after taking on  two stacks of Nurgle and a garrison. 
- Tech trees are pretty bad. The benefits they provide have been heavily nerfed and make little difference.
- Some chaos units are shared reskins between the factions.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Evolution, Technical Performance, Long-Term Value

review_text: I really like this game. I feel like it's a distillation of the first two games' mechanics into something clean and smooth while including so much new content. I love how diplomacy works with the new interface, making the task of making multiple actions with different factions much quicker and easier to accomplish. #3 also introduces a lot of quality of life improvements and cool game mechanics. Also, the return of unwalled town defenses is something that I truly missed in the first two games. Having the entire map open and filled with various factions is super cool. Graphics look great and show a marked improvement since #1. The tutorial is an entire mini-campaign in itself instead of a quick battle and, even as a Total War vet who knows how to play already, it was still well worth playing for the story and the fun scenario. As far as cons go, I can't say I've run into anything yet that really bothers me. It may happen still but, so far, I have no complaints.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, User Interface & Quality of Life, Content & Feature Evolution

review_text: Multiplayer game play has vastly improved with the new simultaneous turn system, which is great. I was really surprised they went to the effort and time to do it (considering people have been asking for it since the dawn of time), not only that but that it was implemented so well. Multiplayer campaigns with friends no longer take an hour to do 3-4 turns.                                                                                                                                                                   Unfortunately the new campaign is BS. It's different but not so enjoyable and the replay value just isn't there. The campaign is very limiting to a few armies, no conquering the world or friends, no large incomes etc. Just a giant 4 or part 5 quest to win, in which the computer/AI blatantly cheats.  The AI bypassing other factions they are at war with just to make a beeline straight for you is at worst game-breaking and best just straight up annoyingly stupid.                                                                                                                                                          The performance isn't good enough either. Bugs and the occasional crash on launch is fine but, it's fairly slow and stutters a lot. It lags during other factions turns also which is strange because it looked to run absolutely fine on any streams that I watched previous to launch.                                                                                                     Wait until they have introduced a proper campaign that doesn't force you down a narrow path simply to make the AI look like it functions, when it still doesn't and nobody is fooled anyway.                                                           Wait until they have fixed or removed whatever it is that has drastically removed the performance you'd expect from a CA/TW game that costs a small fortune.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Innovation, Content Quality, Replay Value

review_text:
Just completed my first campaign, and I'm now able to honestly review the game.

I honestly really enjoyed/enjoy this game!

The Prologue is absolutely amazing!

The campaign was for the most part really good, it has a lot of really fleshed out and intriguing characters and mini story lines that we all know and love from the Warhammer Lore.
There was a few minor elements of the campaign that weren't enjoyable (very minor) such as the settlement battles and the enemy AI which depending on what faction you play as can feel like a Terminator chasing you wherever you go (regardless of there own safety), but not to the point of making me want to stop!

There were a few bugs., wasn't a great issue and most I saw will most likely get scooped up in the next update or two. 
To be expected with a new release, not sure why people are whinging about this...

This game has released at such a great start point that when they do drop in Mortal Empires, it's going to make this games "replay" ability HUGE!

CA has a great record with its previous two titles in the Warhammer series, with frequent DLC additions that can expand and sometimes completely change the way the game can be played! 

Super excited to see what they bring with W3!
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Gameplay Experience, Technical Performance

review_text:
TLDR at bottom
A prime time to write a review because of Current Controversy.
For further Interest I wrote a review for the Second one.

Pros
Hundreds of hours at least of game play(If you enjoy Total war games/Warhammer).
The people who code the game are cool people who seem to actually care, the same for the Lore writers.
Mods Mods Mods. You can get free factions, Free Maps, Free battle maps.

Cons
Total war games have been going downhill since Rome 1, So many features removed.
- Games are Simplified in every single new game that I have played.
---For example things that were in previous Total war games. 
*Actual population management.
*Naval battles (Of course these never made sense to me anyways so not much of a loss here but SOME people do want it)
*Every city could build every building if you could afford it, and resources were in its province.
*Cities had the buildings you built in their battle maps
*Unit Ai that was intelligent.(Opens paths for allied squads to run through, Would cycle front line with those ordered to attack the same unit to lower combat exhaustion)
*Unit and settlement Art.
*Battle deployables.
-This is pretty much Total War 1 Just with a different map and "new." Same engine as Napoleon?
*Really not upgrading engines instead of making a new one is not bad, but how much cost did they save? More on this later.
-Bugs never get fixed.
*Artillery and Ranged units not firing even with full clear line of sight.
*Ranged units Ramboing into melee because of LINE of Sight Errors only to get rocked hard by actual front liners.
*Some campaign missions just not being winnable due to bugs.(without mods that is)
*Some units not being able to be recruited by their Faction.

HOLY FRICK THEY FIXED THE ROLL FOR MORE WINDS OF MAGIC!

---The main Con that EVERYONE is upset at now. The con I addressed in my Review of Total war 2. Pricing.
It is outrageous. It has been outrageous how much they want to charge for a DLC. I tried haggling prices down saying Put new dlc down to 2$ Expecting them to meet me partway and put the DLCs at 7$-15$ (as I understood 2$ was never going to happen)Instead of 20-30$ per dlc. 
Also The Company Pretty much(Summed up by other members of the community) released a statement threatening to drop support for the game all-together if DLC is not bought at their pricing.

This is the I told you so paragraph ----V
-I have been told I do not matter because of this approach. We all look like idiots at some time in our life. I seemed stupid In my last review but It seems the people who perpetuated the Money game to this situation are the true fools who will now drown in their own filth at least for a while. You guys ruined it for everyone, and still have the gall to tell me that I am wrong and do not matter. Amazing

Total Price of Total war Warhammer 3 With all Races unlocks 440.77$

TLDR: Game is amazing, The People who Actually made it are amazing, The community is even pretty cool. The people who set the prices should be blacklisted from the industry and all their pay garnished.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Depth, Developer Support

review_text:
What should have been Creative Assembly's crowning achievement has instead become one of its greatest embarrassments.  Not even accounting for its trainwreck of a release and miserable base game experience prior to Immortal Empires, Total War: Warhammer 3 is a perfect example of a game the developers and publishers care nothing for, other than enhancing their financial bottom line. 
Bugs and glitches that have existed since at least Total War: Warhammer 2 (I'm looking at you, gate bug) continue to persist, despite years of "patching".  Worse, the patch rate for the game is barely a hobble, with patches only coming out when major content updates occur.  This means bugs, like Nakai the Wanderer being unable to recruit Kroxigors (a lord who, I should remind you, was PAID DLC for Warhammer 2) persist for months at a time, despite the fix being proven by modders to be no more difficult than a single line of code.  There are HUNDREDS of problems, both minor and major, with the game that have existed for ages now and show no sign of being fixed or repaired. 
The price increase is the straw that broke the camel's back.  It's an out of touch, outright disrespectful change that proves what the fans have known for a long time: Creative Assembly doesn't care about their game, and they don't care about us.  The price increase would come with grumbling acceptance if, otherwise, CA showed any outward sign of caring for one of their most successful game series ever.  Instead, they continue to let their game be broken, while shovelling the bare minimum amount of content into a paid DLC, while bumping up the price with the excuse of "increased costs" as their only justification. 
Do not buy this game.  Do not play this game.  The developer and publisher don't care about this game, so neither should you.

EDIT: 
Coming to edit because Creative Assembly has not learnt their lesson.  They pretend to care by providing "patches" and "bug fixes" that instead introduce old or new issues that persist for MONTHS at a time with no acknowledgment.  This review was prompted by the (re?) introduction of a bug that prevents the AI for factions like the Lizardmen and Tomb Kings to do NOTHING.  At all.  They sit idly and allow the player and other factions to do as they please with no response at all.  CA did not acknowledge this until a certain major youtuber made a video on the issue; CA then released a statement pretending to care, pretending that this issue has been on their radar "for some time", and that we can expect it to be fixed at the end of October 2025. 
It has been about ten months since the Omens of Destruction DLC came out, and we have received little information on the Tides of Torment DLC.  One DLC a year for the only game actually bringing in revenue for CA is an abysmal rate of content release, almost insultingly low.  They have been almost radio silent on the DLC, likely because it has been messy or because this is the final DLC.  That is my suspicion, based on their lack of willingness to work on the game's problems and release information on this DLC or any future content. 
The siege "rework" will never be finished.  This series sieges have been a mess since game 1, and they never sorted it out.  All the changes they've made over the series life have been trivial at best, terrible at worst, and are indicative of a key trait of CA's development: they don't play their own game.  They throw changes out there and hope the community loves it.  
Do not buy.  This review will never change its rating because they will NEVER fix the issues that need to be fixed.  Sieges will remain broken, buggy, and unfun.  This game will never reach the potential shown when the series was first revealed.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Developer Support, Consumer Value

review_text:
Solid game! Bought full retail, no dlc, and I'm already happy with my purchase. Haven't played Total War since Rome/Shogun, and I was never super into it, but I find myself drawn to this one, the Warhammer Universe just suites it so well. Even just playing Cathay has given me tons of fun battles and opportunities to execute different strategies and improve control and battle tactics. With the challenging campaign map on default settings (for me), I've already gotten a good 100 hours out of this.

It's a shame they don't have cutscenes for assassinations and character actions, but I don't think they've had that since Shogun?
Still -- Imagine a goblin attempting to assassinate a warboss, but just before he strikes, a purple ork pancakes him with a maul from the shadow.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Experience, Narrative Immersion

review_text: I love this game and used to play it all the time. However I got a new computer recently and noticed that textures, health bars, and movement arrows no longer show consistently (They flicker out of visibility so I cant see what units are where, if they are dying, or if they are moving). Turns out if you have an RTX 5070, 5080, or 5090 there is a known issue where this happens. They have known about it since those cards came out (at this point 10 months ago) and haven't fixed it or found a solution. So I guess I'm done playing it since I can't anymore. Goodbye Warhammer Total Wars, I will miss you greatly

review_text:
Instead of being CA's magnum opus we get a game that is objectively less functional and arguably less enjoyable than TW:Warhammer II so SEGA can chase an already dead trend with Hyenas. A game nobody asked for, nobody wanted and will almost certainly be DoA.

Despite the immense size of Immortal Empires and the abundance of factions, magic and units, the experience itself becomes stale rather quickly. Once you've secured your starting area and built a couple of solid armies there is almost nothing left to challenge you as the AI is literally incapable of even trying to erect an Illusion of opposition. At turn 200 they'll be running around with crapstacks, happily yeeting them into your fortified cities just to slightly inconvenience you while you are busy sacking their main realm. The only AI factions that are actually able to snowball to endgame are the ones that are able to confederate as they get a massive boost, so have fun facing the same AI blobs in every lategame campaign.
Once you've dealt with them (which usually turns out to be extremely easy because the AI's armies are completely worthless) the game turns into a boring and tedious map painting simulator. 
The endgame crises, which were supposed to be these exciting scenarios that were going to challenge the player in unique ways also turned out to be worse than the Chaos Invasion from TW:WH I, as they literally just spawn a bunch of doomstacks within their Factions original realms. Very creative. 
Sieges and especially settlement battles are somehow worse than they were in Rome II, a game which released a decade ago.

I could go on and on, as I haven't touched on most of the games issues like the absurd amount of bugs, powercreep, lack of love for older factions and DLC price policy, etc. But I've already put in more work writing this review than CA has into actually polishing this game. At this point I can only hope the inevitable flop of Hyenas will finish the company for good so SEGA can finally take CA out back and shoot them. Perhaps a more competent developer will come along and pick up the IP and bring Total War back to it's former glory.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Depth, AI Competence

review_text: Cool ghame with hors
Review_Angles: Gameplay Appeal, Content Quality

review_text:
I bet my opinion of the game will improve significantly given time and the new grand campaign mode that is to come, but for now I have had so much difficulty with technical issues, messy AI, graphical oddities and overwhelmingly-downgraded UI that my opinion of this game is very negative. The amount of crashes I have had from alt-tabbing has made it difficult to want to open the game knowing that it will likely crash if I dare tab out to click on a YouTube video or something. The gameplay itself is pretty decent and I have had bouts of fun with it, but after having such a great experience with previous Total War: Warhammer titles that did not suffer from a plethora of weird problems this game feels like a downgrade, even alongside all of the improvements they have made to sieges, coop, etc. At the moment I wish they had simply added this game's factions as DLC for Warhammer 2 instead of releasing an entirely new game. I will eventually update this review to recommended when the problems get kinked out.

Update: Too lazy to update in detail, but CA has improved on many of the game's flaws and I have begun recommending it to friends.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, User Interface & Experience, Comparative Franchise Evaluation

review_text:
If you've played the previous two games in the series or like Total War games in general, it is probably worth buying this game. I've seen some reviews complaining about it's quality as an RTS game, Total War games are turn based strategy games, they have real time battles, but are not really trying to compete in the RTS arena. If you are buying this as an RTS game, you are going to be disapointed. 

The new faction mechanics and updates to the campaign are mostly improvements and add variety from previous titles, but it did launch with bugs that while they haven't totally broken the game. The worst bugs and campaign quirks have been or getting fixed rapidly, but if you've never played a Total War game before you might want to pick up an older title and see if you like the genre first.

Biggest complaint so far is that the update/patching process invalidates in previously saved games, this has not happened previously in Total War games for every update and it's annoying it you don't have the time to sit down and play days at a time in one go.
Review_Angles: Genre Expectations, Comparative Value, Technical Quality
