review_text:
Bought this game and really fell in love with it. Overtime I bought all the DLC because I felt like I could play that game for a long while and wanted to show some support to the company for creating something that I really liked.

However, as time went by, I realised that the game contains a good amount of bugs. Some are more trivial than others and even though I believe that bugs are a part of developing a game, I feel like there's a lack of support by the company.

The last bug that got introduced with some good additional content basically broke 2 races (the AI does not do anything with those 2 races - it is a very critical bug), and we have been told by the company that it is gonna be fixed at the next DLC release which is in at least few weeks or even a month. I can understand that with new content, some things may not be working properly. What I cannot accept nor understand is when there's a critical issue being introduced, the focus and priority must switch on solving that issue instead of working on more additional content. At least if we had the ability to "revert" the changes but we do not. For these reasons, I am leaving a negative review.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Company Support

review_text:
Well, what a waste of time.

I used to like this game a lot. I wanted to like it more than 2 because the Old World is my favourite of the Warhammer settings. Having so many of the factions is a real sweet treat. Unfortunately, it seems to be a detriment.

A combination of a buggy release, so many bugs remaining after patch after patch, cut content locked behind dlc, more network errors than even 2, dlc having less content than usual (Looking at you Shadows of Change) and CA’s piss poor handling of this debacle as pushed me to no longer wish to play this game. It’s a shame too, because it has wonderful QoL changes (such as 8 player multiplayer which is absolutely kickass), but unfortunately my issues listed above keep it from being truly awesome.

If you want any advice, I recommend playing the second Warhammer game. You’ll get a solid map that doesn’t have as many issues running and you’ll also get an actual working game.

EDIT 1: Since my initial review, the game has gotten much better. It is now a a point where it is better than the second one.

EDIT 2: CA is something else.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Content Value, Developer Support

review_text:
Been playing since WH1 (OG Rome TW more specifically). Lots of potential but very minimal work is being put into hotfixes and additional content, and there is no free content added that is worthwhile compared to WH2. No groundbreaking innovations compared to its predecessor. I've played a few campaigns at release, Daemons are fun, except you Nurgle, then I waited for Immortal Empires. It ended up being a mess.
So I've waited months for things to get better, and watched from afar if their bugfixes and big content promises would be done. They did not. How surprising considering 3K patches, and they were better.
Chaos Dwarves got released at last for 25 euros. Maybe I'd have bought it later on when I might have played again, but it's quite expensive for an expansion. 25 euros is the cost of Hades, a very polished game with more replayability than a new faction. Then the new DLC price got leaked and it became clear by that point I had lost all interest in the game as it is, and TW in general. The leak was true, 3 lords and a skeleton crew of units. For 25 euros. Might probably be the combined price of both Hades and its coming sequel.

There is no point buying this game now, it's disgustingly expensive, buggy and unfinished. There are no cheap DLC deals for newcomers offered, and if you didn't buy them one release after an other like I was able to, that's a tremendous amount of money.

Try it later, much later, when the patch cycles are finished and *community* hotfixes will have fixed game breaking bugs affecting previous DLCs (looking at you Kroxigors, Ariel). 
Maybe CA will finally understand that actively continuing development of a game is better and safer for both their consumer base and themselves money and trust wise, and take notes from Larian Studios. They should. Because they've lost what little goodwill was left after what they did to Three Kingdoms with this. 
I feel sorry for the developers who want the best for this game, but are not given an opportunity to: you are not the culprits.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Content Quality, Developer Support

review_text:
This is a good game. I will say though, that i much prefer TWWH2 for various reasons and i will go into those below. 
Pros:
 - New races
 - New race-specific mechanics
 - New campaign that almost exclusively shows you all the new races and mechanics
 - "Simultaneous" turns are nice, but you are limited from various things at times or are whipped out of commands when battles start and such. Can't diplomacy while waiting for turn to end, etc. (also a con)
Cons:
 - Graphics when not in battle are inferior compared to legacy games, tend to be pastel/crayon looking and have odd filters
 - New races negate many things from legacy races, example is that old character duelists are now useless against lords larger than them (Queek is now awful)
 - New races (to my taste) are generally just not fun to deal with, large problem in main campaign, but not as large of a problem in Immortal empire campaigns
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Visual Design, Comparative Balance

review_text:
Edit as of 11.10.2025:
Well, I guess I was being quite naive, thinking that CA has somehow learned from their past mistakes and has actually started to try earn some trust back. As it stands, this game is a mess, and even though as a High Elves enjoyer I was extremely looking forward to the next DLC, I think I will pass. If CA does not have any respect towards its actual consumers, who buy the product, then I see no point in financially supporting them anymore.

I thought this game was important to them, being their current biggest title, raking a lot of income and all, but I guess not. Well, keep up at this, CA, and you can be sure you will lose all your customer base. I do not think I will be buying any new title.

I will keep the older review here, just to remind myself not to trust them that easily again.

CA has made some effort to actually address the underlying issues of this game. Patches are now more frequent, DLCs have also stepped up in quality. So, for now, I cautiously reccomend this game. However, the state of the game and more importantly, CA's approach was so, so bad I am not deleting my original review. CA still has to do a lot of work to get my goodwill back. For now, I am cautiously optimistic, but wary.

While this game is fun, with immense amount of content, races, playstyles and therefore replayability, I cannot in good conscience reccomend this game to any new players, because of the awful state it is in right now. There are myriads of bugs that have gone unaddressed now for months. You cannot enjoy some of the additional payed content, as for example Ariel is impossible to recruit in Wood elves campaigns, Nakai cannot recruit his signature unit, and so on. The worst part is that the company is very well aware of all of those issues and more, but they seem to not care at all. This is absolutely insane and unacceptable - such anti-consumer practices should never be tolerated.
So, until the company drastically changes its policy and actually delivers on the promise of frequent patches and hotfixes that would lead the game out of this dark forest full of bugs that it is currently in, no new players should even think of investing into this.
Also, the new pricing for DLCs is so over the top, it feels like a slap in the face to the community.

Edit as of 10.11.: The company has fixed some of the most egregious bugs, but the game is still far from being in an ok state. Also, to top it all off, their communication towards the community has become so arrogant I am starting to wonder whether they actually want their company to fail. Right to discuss is not a privilege, CA, it is my right as a customer I gained by buying your game. Get yourselves together fast, CA, or you will be left with no customer base.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Company Trust, Product Quality

review_text:
So I'd thought I'd post this whilst I'm playing it so I can try and remember at least half of everything that's terrible and sucks with it. The list is long.

From retarded units that just don't follow orders and do really random stuff to consistently lose you battles in otherwise easy conditions to win... down to the horrible Clash of Clans copy (at around £100 a pop).

Seriously this game is the worst of every Total War ever made. Just don't buy it. Ever.

The controls are Janky at best and units following instructions is kind of total RnG. I've got hours of recorded footage of telling archers to shoot at units and they just glitch out on the spot for a few minutes trying to change direction or formation into something that just makes no sense or wasn't requested. Again, usually at a time when you need something to do what you tell it to.

Lost the same siege battle 4 times over with mechanised units driving into trees and just staying there without response to new directions, threats or the 400 enemy troops just strolling past next to you.

Seriously, above all else the completely awful unit A.I. makes this game just unplayable... tell a unit to attack something, it'll change direction and formation for 10 minutes, then walk off in a random direction and stand next to the unit you told it to attack.

Getting units to attack Hero's is even worse. It's like your units do a little dance around the target for 15 minutes whilst they all die.

EDIT: - Sorry I forgot to add that the CPU doesn't play by any of the same rules that you do. So 10 turns in it'ss apear with 2 x 20stacks of units generated from a single town with 3 buildings... Completely impossible in any of the game mechanics... You can tell when someone has made a really unbalanced non-working bag of crap when the AI is just coded to ignore all game constraints and just throw massive armies at you whenever and however required... usually crap in your units vs CPU units as well in terms of how they behave etc. in battle... loads of completely stupid movements by your own units to aid the CPU at just the right times...

Please for god sake don't buy this game. Grab yourself a £89 parachute instead and try Base Jumping. It's less painful.

EDIT : You could throw a bag of razor blades and a few pints of Vinegar into the sky dive mentioned above and still be good... I wouldn't play this anymore if I was paid to. THere are £4 indie games with just way more to offer...

Well done CA - Waited 4 years for the final on this title and you turned it into an unbalanced, Jankie, Cheap feeling, Overpriced Clash of Clans copy... Outstanding work...

BTW - Whichever idiot OK'd the £100 a copy Tower Defence Game... Please ****ing sack them. Worst RTS game ever made.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Mechanics, Consumer Value

review_text:
This game has greatly affected me on a emotional, physical, spiritual, cognitive and financial level. I no longer even find joy in killing enemies on the other team, the short lived joy from the tiny squirt of dopamine that was once released isn't released anymore. I only find mild solice in the thought that killing an enemy will be bringing upon them the hardships this game has bought upon me. This game will turn you into a masochist in where the only pleasure you will find in playing this game will be derived from the pain you will receive by playing it.

I'm hoping if you're here reading the reviews for Total War: Warhammer III you haven't yet decided to sell your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ soul to the snail and download this plague on your computer, if you answer yes to any of the following question this game is not for you. Forget it ever existed, do not return.

Do you enjoy life?
Do you like more then 4 hours of sleep a night?
Would you like stability within your life?
Do you like having good relations with your family and friends?
Would you like to keep your job?


However, if you answer yes to any of these following questions this game is perfect for you.

Do you enjoy eating lead house paint and crayons?
Would you like to sit in front of a computer screen for hours a day neglecting every aspect of your life and finding no joy at all in what you're doing, all in order to unlock pixels that resemble a deamon only to die to a 13 year old Estonian child and his dad's credit card?
Do you have severe anger issues?
Would you like to pull each of your finger nails off with a pair of pliers?
Do you have no friends or want to lose them all?
Would you enjoy kicking a toothpick under you toe nail into a wall?
Review_Angles: Emotional Impact, Gameplay Addiction, Consumer Warning

review_text:
The game "Total War: Warhammer 3" is not good. The culmination of all the previous games and their paid DLC as "Total War: Warhammer: Immortal Empires" is amazing. This is an investment, a very expensive investment. The game by itself is not good, and all its content is locked behind paid DLC. The game even came out with pre-order paid DLC, and then months later the factions that you bought the game for also have units locked behind more paid DLC. Do not Buy this game, or any Total War: Warhammer game/DLC at full price. Check everywhere you can for discounts. None of the content is worth the full asking price. 

All that aside, after you have forked over money for the content, it is "good." The game has many bugs and factions have varying levels of uniqueness, power, and content. Immortal Empires is a mashup of games from up to 7 years ago, and you can tell when playing it. Luckily those games were very good, so the experience over all is good. 

I would not recommend this game to a new player. If you already have one of the older games, or are a fan of Warhammer or Total War then Immortal Empires is probably the best game you will find (with the highest price to entry you will find).
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Monetization Model, Content Quality

This game is amazing!!

I am doing my part here to remind the audience, amidst the recent super negativity around Warhammer, that the depth of the world and the completeness of the game blasts the industry standard out of the water. This game is is a thrill and is always different. I love this game! It's made specifically for people like me that love the macro-play.

As of late, I noticed that this new patch (I haven't played it) has inspired over 7,200 people to bomb it in the reviews. The game is amazing! People are just passionate and make their issues bigger than the overall picture of the game.

Thanks for reading.

review_text:
I love the franchise, I love warhammer, and I love strategy battle games. There truly is no gaming experience quite like a Total War Campaign. 


Unfortunately, this entry into the series has been wholly without heart on the part of Creative Assembly. Warhammer 1 and 2 were both well received, and the studio limped into the finish line with this absolutely uninspired installment. The release was terrible, the updates have been glacial, and the "improvements" in the game since release have largely been lateral moves.


Don't get it twisted - this game is getting review bombed, but not JUST because of CA's latest chicanery. This is the final straw for a lot of us who have watched CA fritter away its opportunity to make this into the game that this franchise deserves. If I believed for one second that my money would actually go to the stewardship of this game, I would continue to buy full priced DLC happily, but it is clear that CA would rather leave a skeleton crew with minimal resources supporting their flagship title.


For new customers, I would recommend Rome 2 over this game, and for Warhammer fans, Warhammer 2 Total War is a lot better than 3.
Review_Angles: Developer Support & Updates, Game Quality & Innovation, Franchise Expectations

review_text:
It's a really great way to play Total War, once you have everything. The world itself is really interesting and pulled me into it, finding ways to cheese the game or just do well with classic military strategy is deeply satisfying, and the variety of factions make the Immortal Empires campaigns endlessly replayable. 

Get the lot in the biggest sale you can, as the game is really all three TW:WHs stitched together. The campaign specific to this game is nothing special, and its unique mechanics aren't that interesting. Immortal Empires lets you play as any of the legendary lords from all of the factions released from the first TW:WH to this one - provided you have each game and its respective DLC, anyway - one a world-sized map. I played a few campaigns before finishing the collection and often felt like something was missing, only to find out later a DLC picked up later on had the exact kind of units I wished was there. 

If you loved TW when you were younger and want to scratch that itch, this is perfect. It's just costly to scratch.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Experience, Content Variety

review_text:
I have only played the intro/Tutorial campaign of TW: W III, after playing a couple hundred hours each of TW: WI and TW:W II.  Story of the campaign was fine, but I didn't like the UI changes with the third instalment of this series.

Specifically, I did not like the changes to the item equip menu/screen.  In TW:II, the dropdown menus for each item type made it easy to review: a) what items were available for each slot; b) what each of these items did; and, c) who currently had particular items equipped.  While the current screen may be more aesthetically pleasing, I found it did not communicate information as clearly or easily as the old system.  Even in the tutorial campaign, managing items across characters felt like more of a chore.  YMMV, of course.

On that note: if you are looking to jump into the series, I suggest buying your collection somewhere other than Steam.  As of writing, I have put only 4 hrs, 36 mins into TW:W III over two days of play (to give a fulsome play of the tutorial, to make sure I wasn't unfairly bouncing off of the newest iteration just because it is the newest).  This is, I believe, the first Steam refund I've asked for.  It was repeatedly rejected, apparently automatically, with a short statement that it didn't meet the 14/2 rules for automatic refunds.  Despite me repeatedly taking time to point out that Steam's own policy claims that refund requests *that don't meet the 14/2 rules* will still be looked at, and despite noting the significant play time required to *finish the tutorial campaign*, compared to other games.   So, cavaet emptor.
Review_Angles: User Interface Design, Comparative Gameplay Experience, Information Clarity

review_text:
+Cool setting. Amazing characters. Different playstyles. Many cool units. Very well voiced.
+++Incredible mod support. Half of what I like about the game has come from one or another mod. Game is great without it but after you install some of the mods you kind of start feeling they are mandatory for your playthroughs.

-Ridiculously dumb AI, resource intensive, bland combat encounters due to bad AI
---CA (the developers) gets very dumb every couple months, then they are cool. That's just a toxic relationship, but you stay because the good times are great.

Overall it's a great game. Buy DLC when on sale. Game is great if you are into the setting, are a fan of fantasy or guns. If you are only in it for gameplay then it's more of a 6/10 meh.

Personally I've played for thousands of hours and I've enjoyed 90% of them.

review_text:
Don't listen to negative sheep, get the game, play it and enjoy yourself.
So far I have had 2 problems in my 100+ hours of playing, the game crashed twice. Other than that I loved playing the story from the prologue, battling in new village combat and customising my Daemon Prince. 
Most negative reviews (not all of them) I have seen are from people who's computer is on par with the Xbox 360, they don't understand whats being spelled out to them so they are huffing or quite simply expecting a new game to be like a christmas tree popping up fully decorated with the lights plugged in at the click of their fingers, sorry doesn't happen like that.
Is this a game for everyone? No. No game is.
Does it have issues? ALL GAMES HAVE ISSUES. remember that duplication glitch in the original Pokemon Red/Blue? of course you do, you used it alot.
Reviews can destroy a games chance at getting to its full potential so please before leaving one just think real hard until most of you realise the problem is you not the game.

review_text:
Bigger, but definitely not better than the second game.

Quite a lot of bugs (Nakai can't recruit Kroxigors, problems with Ariel, LoS of ranged units etc.) and "unfinished" content, that desperately need revisiting (e.g. generic skill trees of many older characters don't even have enough skills for all 49 skill points - really annoying in the endgame when level-up notifications pop up - promised to be fixed in 2022, but who cares).

Sieges and AI are still bad and it looks like they don't have any good idea how to make them better, because rework was bad. Immortal Empires, while big and looks fantastic, becomes dull after 50-70 turns. There is lack of side goals or content, only one big sandbox where you paint the huge map.

Upcoming DLC costs 50% of the full game, brings less content to the table than normally and they justify that by saying "their costs are up". Their revenue almost tripled in the last 5 years and they make £6m profit.
CA adapts to the "current standards", but in my opinion those are Activision standards. Let's enjoy less for more money, with patches every 6 months and less communication with the fanbase.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Design, Content Value

review_text:
Very dodgy launch, lack of sandbox is very frustrating, and certain issues such as far too many siege battles that have to be played as the auto resolve function has been balanced to make you suffer more losses. Campaign also lacks massive replayability and has some annoying mechanics, though those have largely been patched out by now. 

All that being said, the game is still a boat load of fun, animations and unit designs are gorgeous and the individual factions are awesomely unique. I'm having a lot of fun, and ontop of that i have a pretty crappy rig too (last and most modern piece of kit in it is a GTX 1060), though the game easily runs well enough to enjoy. While siege battles get repetitive the battles and fighting in the game is still badass and the new settlement battles are a MASSIVE improvement on TWW2,though some people dislike the tower system, and I certainly would have preferred a system based around other tools like barricades, fire pits etc as in previous tw titles. 

It's in a problematic place, though still worth it in my book, hundreds of hours of fun still to be had and a ton more content to come as well that will keep you busy. The issues many people report about I personally haven't found to be that invasive in my enjoyment of the game at all, and the modding community is already cranking out plenty of cool stuff on TWW3 if your into that side of things as well.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, Visual Design

review_text:
So, a response was finally given to us by CA about the unjustifiable pricing of the Shadows of Change dlc.
To sum it up: "shut up, buy it and be grateful".
Its the same cost as a racepack, but with the content of a lordpack (and NO, including bug fixes for things YOU broke FROM THE LAST GAME doesn't count as price-justifying content. Embarrassing that was used as an argument btw). It's genuinely so disappointing that such a phenomenal setting bound to such a strong and engaging game formula is fostered by a company like CA. 
They're just looking to subsidize the cost for their dumb Hyenas game that's gonna fail, CA community managers are doing their best but of course all of the fallout lands on their heads and none of it on the greedy corporate troglodytes wasting the company resources on a trend-chaser bound for failure.

I will not be buying this DLC until it is on a heavy sale, and if CA keeps up I will not be purchasing anything from them ever again. I have 1600 hours on WH2 and almost 400 on WH3, along with every dlc, and this is enough to push even me away.

I would not recommend purchasing the game as of this moment. The ongoing quality of the product is constantly in question due to the incompetence and greedy decisions of the developers.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Corporate Strategy, Community Relations

review_text:
Let me tell in the beginning what I'll tell as the conclusion: This game does not deserve its Mixed rating. It's currently a good game, with potential to be the greatest Total War game with the inclusion of Immortal Empires, race DLCs, some bugfixes, tweaks and performance improvement.

The biggest criticism to the game right now is how the campaign narrative plays: travelling to the chaos realm and completing missions there. I agree that completing a realm feels unrewarding afterwards (compared to the trouble you take), but the realm idea in general is really cool. Another related criticism is the campaign being on a timer: you're in a race with other factions. I really understand that people enjoy sandbox experiences more, but that is for Immortal Empires update. We all knew that WH3 would launch with a more narrative, race campaign, like WH2. And I can see no degradation from Race for the Vortex campaign of WH2.

After this, the following are pros and cons of WH3 in my opinion, coming from someone that really liked WH2.

Pros:
[list]
[*] For the first time in TW WH trilogy, siege battles are fleshed out.
[*] In the older games, making military alliances was only meaningful with superpowers. This time, the allegiance mechanic makes it useful and super interesting to make more alliances. If nothing, I really liked the idea of incorporating my fav units from different races into my armies.
[*] The game introduces 8 new races that capture the detail that we're used to from WH2, with very unique units and interesting faction mechanics. So more of the same standard in that regard, which is a plus.
[*] UI and accessibility is greatly improved. Your units are more visible, their cards convey more information (like when they are idle), selecting a spell slows down the game seamlessly - making it easier to cast.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] While they have an interesting concept, I didn't find playing survival battles fun. Note that you have to play only a handful of them, if you don't autoresolve.
[*] Completing realms at the moment is very unrewarding. Plus, the Tzeench realm feels very unfair to compete against the AI.
[*] Performance is not as good as WH2.
[*] It shouldn't be that you plow through in Hard campaign difficulty, but deal with endless hordes of enemies in Very Hard. The difficulties should be better organized.
[*] Especially the Chaos factions have a limited number of units, which will undoubtedly be addressed in DLCs - but it's still a negative in the current state.
[/list]
Review_Angles: Game Quality Assessment, Future Potential, Campaign Design

review_text:
Very good fantasy war simulation game with good graphics, epic music, and high mod support in both singleplayer and multiplayer. It got a lot of great improvements to gameplay of previous installments. The main campaign is a decent story, though not as good as Total War:Warhammer 2 Vortex Campaign. 

But the main mode to play is the Immortal Empires mode, that expands the map to cover all 3 games and factions in one scenario. If you own the previous games or dlcs, you can play as the factions from those games. Otherwise you can only play as the Total War:Warhammer 3 factions. Immortal Empires is an amazing experience not found in other games.

review_text: this is not a product worth 60€ at this moment. For 60€ i expect a polished and most importantly *Finished* game, not a fucking early access game being marketed as a full release. On the higher graphic settings the ui looks like crap, when zooming out on the battle map small units like Nurglings turn into shapeless blobs of colour which is frankly unacceptable in a 60€ game with like years of development. During the Prologue the game softlocked twice on me as i didnt act exactly as the tutorial intendet. apart from that during normal campaigns i have also been softlocked a number of times, for example in my most recent campaign (as Tzeentch) the chaos rifts straightup do not spawn preventing all factions from gaining demon souls and completing the campaign (it has been 140 turns and none have shown up), It has also crashed on me several times already. And speaking of the demon souls mechanic, i absolutly hate it. the survival battles are a massive slog and genuinly unfun in my opinion. On a positive note i quite like the customisation of the demon prince but his campaign is arse as the AI has such massive player Bias that it feels all but impossible to even leave your starting province as you just run along the coastline facing twenty stack after twenty stack and FUCKING KOSTALTIN all the time. This game doesnt feel like a 60€ game release this feels like a 20€ early access title you backed for some reason you cannot remember anymore. This is a straight downgrade fro, WH 2. Not worth 60€ and CA should be ashamed for thinking that its ready for release.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Visual Quality

review_text:
The latest DLC is the straw to break the back, I was waiting and waiting for the fixes and post launch love that never came. 
After always have the latest TW game downloaded and usually spending 100s of hours on each, this is the first one I uninstalled, the price hike of the same watered down DLC was enough. I did not mind the game on release but the love has gone for the series and I could not get the feeling of wanting to play, despite loading the game and starting a new Campaign, an hour later I would turn the game off, the bugs (some of which would crash my PC after winning battles on certain maps). The overall dullness of the campaign amazed me how my favourite game WH2 could be turned so boring. 

Awkwardly there is a UK branch of Total war CA in my home town that I have to see and laugh at on my way to visit family. 

I hope CA can make a game that can reintroduce me to the series and get the love back, at a price available to all. Nobody is going to buy this over the current games coming out for this price!
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Gameplay Engagement

review_text:
Is this game perfect, no, is this game perfectly polished to a shine, no. Honestly, that's okay. The game is stable but not quite optimized, it eats up performance like a monster but this will change, the game is 100% playable (in a good way) right now. 

Races are fun and all differentiated from each other, it's a strong foundation. The campaign story quests are a little unforgiving for little reward (very in theme for Warhammer though) which drags down the gameplay a little. Despite this, it's still a blast, bugs aside, it's still a blast! I completely understand concerns about bugs, they exist and they will get squashed. I understand concerns about optimization, but I haven't seen it.

If your worried about performance, pull up the prologue and see how far you can get, if that doesn't work, than you know how the rest of the game is going to run. All else aside, the game is a blast! I recommend it to fans now, but for new people, worried about issues, waiting will only make it sweeter!

EDIT: Dev's have let the game slide back to it's terrible state again, coming out with fucked patches... CA needs to do better!
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Experience, Future Potential

review_text: This has been probably the most fun game experience for my friends and myself personally! In our 4 player campaigns we have had shenanigans, back-stabbings, and rallying to each other's support leading to the best time I have had in a multiplayer video game to date! The experience in the story campaigns from a Single Player experience are great. Able to keep myself entertained, even though I am not a single player gamer. Definitely up there for best game of the year so far. Any other releases have a high bar to mantle. Do yourself a favor and get the game, especially if your friends have it as well!
Review_Angles: Multiplayer Experience, Single Player Experience, Overall Recommendation

review_text:
I like the game, aside from the poor launch, but updates have felt slow and infrequent. There have been some good updates such as not having to fight minor settlement battles where its basically capture the flag EVERY minor settlement whether it has walls or not. 

Unfrotunately, as much as I like the game, WH3 has been a far drop from the state the game was in at the end of WH2. I personally felt the DLC was very reasonably priced to the point where I bought it even if I didn't want it. Now it feels like the price of the DLC has been increased massively and disproprtionately. It is a bit better now that they seen to be carving up the DLC and letting you buy the race updates separately, but it's still expensive. You can literally buy whole games for the price of some new units and lords. There's less content that the updates in WH2 and it costs more. they want their cake and to eat it. 

Not to mention the constant issues with bugs and glitches. The game isn't updated that frequently and when it is, it feels like they should have accomplished a lot more in the time. And when new content is prioritised over fixing issues with the game, it feels like the directors see our money as an entitlement rather than something they need to convince us to part with. 

"We've updated the game, you're going to buy it and you'll like it! OR YOU'RE TOXIC"

I do love this franchise crossover of Total War and Warhammer, unfortunately it is being made by a studio that has a leadership problem, whether thats within the studio or their publisher, and I can't recommend you support them buy buying their game when they do not respect you or your time.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Experience, Update Frequency

review_text:
I have purchased every Total War game since Shogun 1 (except Medieval 1).  I have every DLC for the Warhammer series and bought them all upon release.  I really love this game and the franchise.  The truth is I don't think Creative Assembly loves this franchise.  They have fallen in love with the money, taking the revenue from this series to fund other projects.  That was fine when they were still pouring their time and effort into their flagship series.  Now though, they have raised their DLC to $25 for 3 legendary lords and hardly any FLC.  Half the base game for a fraction of the content.  The base game is buggy, and I frankly rely on the modders to make the game be in a state I enjoy playing it (check out SFO--Venris is the best).  I want this game to succeed, but not like this.  I would love to remove this review if CA decides to try to regain some of their goodwill back.  Until then....sad day...

UPDATE:  Thrones of Decay has released and the work CA put in has improved quite a bit.  I will update my review upon the next DLC--if it is of the same caliber.  I want this series to succeed and purchased ToD, but I also want to ensure this wasn't just a fluke.  Keep it up CA :)

Total War Community—will boost rating to positive for now but will reassess upon next dlc release
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Developer Commitment, Technical Stability

With 800 hours now in....  phew!

When this game came out.  I had some issues with the game design that I was not much a fan of.  Issues that stood since WH1 and also WH2.  To date; most of those issues have been corrected or at least improved.

I will say that this game is very little challenge.  Because I can save and load game, whenever.  There is no IronMan mode.

With that being said.  I find this game to be a LOT OF FUN!
It has huge variety and options.  Creative.  Decent mechanics.  And almost all the DLC; I find are fun for me.  I always get them on sale.  Always.

I like this game.  I play it often. 
Immortal Empires, is my fav to play.  I play full Domination Campaigns.  Loooooong games.  But great fun.  I win.

I recommend this game.  It is difficult at times for sure.... but, not....  because I can always re-load a moment previous.  Easy.

review_text: So as you can see by my hours I love this game, I love Total War as a franchise in general, and I have always had the mindset of "Let them fix it when they can" but this has gotten simply ridiculous. I don't blame the devs working on the game for not being able to fix every little bug or accidentally creating new issues. However I do blame the management, and publisher for not putting enough resources into this game. This is an ACTIVELY played game, one of the most popular strategy games, and series of the last 20 years and it's going down the drain. Give the team more staff and some more resources, how can you expect any of us long term fans to buy the next TW, or DLC when you've proven again and again that modders have to fix the game for you?
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Developer Support

review_text:
This game is definitely a step back from where we were in Warhammer 3.  The things that were bad about that game's campaign (the Vortex rituals) only got worse (in the form of portals).  But then they took an enormous step backwards with changes to settlement battles.  Every battle now is a siege; maybe 1 out of 5 battles is in the field, and now the game just feels like a total slog. The only real way I see this getting fixed is if they just the garrison building chain for minor settlements into an actual settlement battle, rather than giving them walls. Then, if you don't have the garrison building chain, minor settlements just cause a field battle instead.

The changes to settlements make the game drastically more difficult, and when every battle is a siege, it very rapidly stops being fun.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Design, Comparative Progression, Player Experience

review_text:
When the game started out it had a lot of problems and over the time it has mainly gotten more problems, one of the biggest is that the game has simply become too easy, power creep since release over the course of many DLC releases means that even playing on the very hardest difficulty giving the AI serious cheats you might not be challenged all that much, there's items giving you +50% campaign movement speed now where 5% used to be a desirable buff, there's bonuses that gives more movement upon winning battles and other such trivialising the campaign, you have to actively go out of your way to avoid them or avoid dlc units that are mostly just a straight upgrade from vanilla faction units. 

Lately ofcourse there's been the dead faction lords problem not moving around, that's got people riled up as well though it's nothing new, it does feel as if the priority here is to release new content and make money while keeping staff working on the rest at an absolute minimum to focus on making the newer titles like 40K, you get where they're coming from but you know they're going to want to package all the DLC under a 'Definitive Edition' some day and that's going to be a hard sell to people since, it's gonna be expensive and they're going to see the reviews aren't great, that's not a good combination, probably should consider the game at some point, best time to do so was before 1.0 but better late than never.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Balance, Technical Performance, Content Evolution

review_text:
So ive been playing a decent amount again the past week or so and I have to say that its nice they stuck with it and ironed out a lot of the issues I had at launch. While still not perfect there have been some major improvements that really allows me to enjoy the game again.

Another positive thing is that CA seems to have learned from their previous years where there was controversy after controversy (Pricing of dlcs, content, etc...). While the jury is still out on if they will keep it up I think the the last 2 dlc releases have been great (Written as of the release of Omens of Destruction). 

After a long time of disliking the game and the way CA has been acting I can say that I would recommend the game in its current state and im hoping for more improvements/dlc that fleshes out the game even more.

Edit for 25-10-2025:
I honestly cant recommend the game with all its problems and power creep. I would wait before getting it and see if CA is able to fix the problems that plague this game or get it on sale.

Written at release:
I love the Warhammer total war series but in all honesty i would wait before buying WH3. 
There are major issues with the game and with the slow release of updates (or even dlc) just makes it so I cant recommend the game in its current state. 
Hopefully CA gets their shit together and Ill be able to recommend the game in the future.

Edit for 16-08-2023:
Still lots of bugs, long time between major patches, and overpriced dlc. If you like warhammer i would just go back to warhammer 2 as that game is in a much better state.
Review_Angles: Post-Launch Support, Consumer Trust, Current State Recommendation

review_text:
Realms of Chaos mode is dog shit. Turns the game into an end turn simulator where you have to tunnel vision the campaign objective and nothing else. And God forbid you let the AI reach four Daemon souls before you, then you will be unable to enter the Forge of Souls to stop them because of a bug, meaning that your campaign that may have taken you dozens of hours is now over and you lost. Can't play anymore, too bad for you.

In case you don't want to lose your save file because of the developers' incompetence, the only solution I've found is to literally go into the game's code and make it so it's impossible for the AI to win the final battle. Thanks CA.

Instructions for saving your campaign if you end up in my situation: Download RPFM. Look for the Data folder in the game's directory. Inside is a file named data.pack. Open this using RPFM (you may want to back this up in case you mess up and brick your game). Once inside navigate to script>campaign>wh3_main_chaos>realms>wh3_realm_common.lua. Look for the line that says "local strength_required_for_ai_to_complete_realm = 2000000;". Just add two more zeroes to that value, go up to the PackFile drop-down menu in the top left and change packfile type to movie, then save. Now it's impossible for the AI to win.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Design, Technical Stability, Consumer Protection

review_text:
I've played the Total War: Warhammer franchise games from the first release, every DLC, and now the third installation. Combined between Warhammer one and two, I have 4100 hours played (I lead a really rewarding life I swear).

I've now put 120 hours into Total War: Warhammer III and my review is this:

The game is not ready. It's an unfinished product with very clear flaws and unfinished parts of the game. Some systems are distinctly worse, or are actually regressions from improvements made in Total War: Warhammer II. After looking at the road map that CA has released, it's clear that this was a very premature release (giggity). I am so freaking tired of half-baked versions of games being released as 'full, completed, and finished' games that spend the next year being patched into a playable and fun experience. That's not a finished game. That's a work in progress. This should have been released as early access, NOT a final release.

Is it a terrible game? No. Is it a vast step down from the second game? Absolutely.

My first complaint is the lack of polish on the battle auto resolve system. I play on Legendary, and I get it. It's supposed to be hard. What I cannot stand, and intensely despise, fake difficulty. This system is a perfect example of fake difficulty. Having to manually fight every single rebellion in my faction, the same way every time, and having to waste hours of my time fighting the exact same battles over and over and over again S U C K S. In the same vein as the rebellions is some random five or ten strength 'army' wading into my lands and teleporting around in the case of Tzeench armies, and laying siege to my settlement. Not being able to autoresolve the battle with my 14-20 army garrison that I should always win, and usually win with very minimal casualties, is infuriating. This isn't difficulty, that's tedious nonsense. Some factions have no hope of avoiding rebellions, such as Slaanesh, and I wound up straight quitting my campaign at about 100 turns in because I just couldn't do it anymore.

The second is the 'new' trait system, which is quite literally just the same trait system from Warhammer I and II before they FIXED IT. 

Why? ... WHY?! WHYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY!?!?!?!

After multiple years of complaining that if your lord wasn't a Disciplined lord they were borderline worthless, we finally got updated traits for lords that actually made them unique and interesting. Wanted a fighter lord? There were finally traits that meaningfully improved their personal statistics. Wanted a lord that focused on buffing the army? We had traits for that, and so on. Why did CA decide to revert that change and go back to a far inferior, less rewarding system that was changed BECAUSE of negative feedback about how bad it was? 'Power creep'. What a lame duck excuse in a single player game. Honestly, I never once heard anyone complain about 'power creep' regarding the lord traits. The changed system in Warhammer II was celebrated and breathed life into otherwise copy-paste bland lord systems. Reverting this change was a very poor decision, and I was extremely disappointed when I opened the lord recruit screen and saw the old trait system again.

Third is the pathing of units and some units dropping commands, getting trapped, or otherwise just not attacking properly. There are some units, like chasing units (such as war dogs, etc), that literally can't do their job because their targeting is absolute trash. They get stuck behind a few units at the back of the unit because they're all auto-locked onto the unit at the 'front' of retreating units, and almost never even actually attack or kill anything. Their one job. Also the ranged units are messed up almost across the board. Most of the time the whole set of units won't fire, or if they're docked on the sides of the city defenses only the first row fires. It's awful.

My final complaint is just the lack of polish on the game as a whole. There are some really cool new additions in this game, but there are a lot of things that took gigantic leaps backwards. It feels like all the improvements Warhammer II made were completely scrapped for no reason, and it's just tragic to see. Instead of just importing the changes Warhammer II made into Warhammer III, now we have to go through the whole process all over again, and I'm just not into it. This just ain't it, chief. I've never asked or even thought about trying to ask for a refund about any game, but I seriously considered it for this one. This is not a completed game. The varnish wears off after about the first ten hours, and if you're a veteran of the franchise you're just left disappointed and annoyed.

Stop. Releasing. Beta. Test. Versions. As. Full. Release. Games. Please.
Review_Angles: Product Completeness, Game Development Practices, Feature Regression

review_text: Despite a few minor bugs, the game is in an excellent state. The AI is borderline cheating, particularly on higher settings, offering a significant challenge for the masochists if you don't cheese the mechanics. Visually, the game is stunning, though it does have some performance issues. I will caveat this with the acknowledgement that some of the DLCs are overpriced, however, going on the latest DLC CA has released, they appear to be listening to the fans and making them worth the money in my opinion.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Challenge, Consumer Value

review_text: With the addition of Immortal Empires and many bugfixes the game is now worth buying. Although Immortal Empires is still in Beta, so if you want to wait until it's fully released, you should wait a couple more months.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Product Completeness

review_text: Game is good.
Review_Angles: Overall Quality

review_text:
There is a ton of content in this game. It is aided by owning the other games to get all of the toys from the previous games. Heroes and unit variation makes the game a little different every time and kept me engaged through my 186 hours of play. I have been playing total war since Rome total war and own almost all the games in this series. I think that the over the top nature of this game is the reason I keep coming back. I also appreciate that CA have kept lore in mind during the creation of factions, heroes, and campaigns. 

I do kind of dislike some of the DLC practices. What I mean by this is there is just a mammoth amount of it and to get all of the content you would have to spend something like $300. That being said, they have also given away a ton of free stuff to the community and seem to really care. 
You will experience bugs and you will find yourself frustrated. However you may also find a game that will keep you coming back for years to come!
Review_Angles: Content & Value, Monetization & DLC, Lore & World-Building

review_text:
Agree with most negative reviewers. The game really punishes you during the chaos rift invasions. If you like puzzle-like games, this might be your cup of tea. But if you play Total Warhammer because you wanted the previous experience of becoming the badass of anything that has a tooth and an eye-socket? You're in for a treat, but the Hansel and Gretel version.

In this game, half the time you're trying to manage a choke point and, oh... 3000 units camped outside your doorstep? Why? Because when the rifts pop-up and you can't close them in time... well... enjoy the bloodbath, but remember, those are your organs on that pretty 4K resolution mountain. And WHILE monsters of every habitat trample joyfully on your hard-earned cities, your neighbour sees a wonderful opportunity to pay your towns a permanent visit. 

Not enough pain for the masochist in the room? Don't forget the chaos gods and their pain-in-the-#@^% domain maps. If the puzzles in those chaos realms aren't enough to take you away from your world domination, we have an added hour-long session with each God. And IF you survive, you can be fairly certain that you're going to be crippled, debuffed, half-lifed and... oh, hey neighbour. :(
Review_Angles: Gameplay Challenge, Genre Alignment, Strategic Management

review_text:
Early review after playing for two days. Will delete/update if opinion changes. So far the game has been very enjoyable but has some rough spots.

First, I'll talk about what I don't like so I can get it out of the way and try to end on a more positive note.
-The Campaign Soft timer: It's a god damn race and even worst then the vortex race. Unlike the vortex campaign there is no way to stop a faction from progressing to the end goal before you without declaring war on them and manually marching a army over to kick their butt. You can use rifts to teleport over to the area they have to go, but nothing stops them from trying again and again. I was planning as Slannesh and the Ogre kingdoms got all the mcguffins and I had no way to stop them short of keeping a army posted on the forge at all times.

-Stability: I have a 3090, AMD 5800x, 32 GB of high speed ram, and a new(ish) motherboard. This game should not be dropping under 60 FPS on the campaign map. What's so odd is that in battles it runs much better, but the campaign seems to have FPS issues. It's probably better to have smooth battles but still, something is clearly wrong. A lot of people are blaming the DRM, but this is the same DRM that was in Warhammer 2 so unless they changed it I am questioning the validity of that. So far I had the game hard crash on me only once. Also there are lots of mostly minor bugs, such as getting stuck in forced march even if you did not move, a slannesh research that breaks their entire faction mechanic, the auto resolve constantly saying your going to die when really your probably going to curb stomp the enemy, just to name a few. Besides that, the AI actually seems to be working mostly well which surprised me because it had a lot of problems in the early release. Though I did have ONE siege battle where the AI picked a random supply spot and decided to defend that and ONLY that while I took the actual victory point.

-The UI. RED ON RED, HOPE YOU LIKE RED CAUSE RED IS ALL WE GOT! Seriously, it's all red. Also it feels cluttered af on the campaign map. All the quest are piled up and there is constant crap popping up in my face. EVERY TIME I go into a siege the advisor is like "DO YOU WANT A RUNDOWN OF HOW THIS WORKS!?" and I can't even click the rundown to make it go away because it appears to be bugged and nothing happens. Also they removed a lot of the artwork and simplified things. 

-Public Order for chaos factions. Having full your corruption gives you a +10, any other corruption being at full expect undivided is -20. If a rift spawns in your land it'll give you like +30 corruption and reach 100 within 3-5 turns. This basically means if your playing a demon faction every time the rifts spawn you have to go on a frantic mad dash to close them in time before rebels appear.

-The rifts: They can spawn anywhere and spread corruption, ok that's fine in theory. It's only 1500 gold with a agent of a small battle with a army to get rid of them. BUT they also spawn armies and let enemies teleport using them, WITHOUT A NOTIFICATION. I normally got warned when a army came out of a rift when the game told me a settlement was besieged. Also as mentioned before, the corruption is WAY TOO HIGH. You'll have 100 corruption of one of the chaos gods within 3-5 turns on average.

-The Start Campaigns: The suggest starting campaign is Kislev or Chaos Undivided. What both these campaigns have in common is that you'll be at war on all fronts nearly constantly. The Ice Court starts with one city, at war with a faction that owns 3 settlements and a city, and two Norse factions. Undivided, I have no idea why but the entire planet just hates undivided. I understand your a demon prince that wants to conquer the planet, but there is a lot of that going around! The AI could pick a fight with Khorn or Nurgle, but instead REALLY LIKES to bully undivided. I understand these factions are the easiest to play in battle, but they can be nightmares on the campaign.

-Allies attacking Vassals: If you are planning on making vassals or playing slannesh. DO NOT DO MILITARY ALLIANCES. The dumbass "allies" will attack your vassals...for some reason. Undivided was getting along just fine with the Norscans until I vassal them, then suddenly they craved blood.

-Infinite respawning barbiarns: If you play Cathay you get hordes of kurgans to deal with nonstop, they can't die. They come back every time, you can't make peace with them as Cathay. Enough said.

OK. ONTO THE GOOD.

-Story: The main improvement I noticed right away was the game has a much better narrative. The advisor has a actual reason to align himself with each faction, the prologue explains who the undivided faction leader is, and the main antagonist actually has some cut scenes and build up.

-Factions: Each faction feels different both in battle and on campaign. The rosters are small, there is no DLC expect for the ogre's yet so don't expect the amount of units Warhammer 2 had with all it's DLC/FLC. There are actually very few reskinned units for the demon factions. Each demon faction get's a forsaken, a spawn, and a fury; besides that all the units among the demon factions are unique. The non-demon factions each felt unique also, none of them felt like the previous factions. Kislev was the most familar out of them but Kislevs strong emphasis on hybrid unit and bear Calvary that function better when allowed to stay in melee instead of cycle charging gave them their own flavor. 

-Campaign map: It looks really good, not much else to say. goes as far as Altdorf and a few of the northern dwarf factions and we get the whole of the chaos waste for the most part. A couple small area's like chaos dwarves appear to be missing but I am hopeful their arrive eventually.

-The Models: Keeping it short, all the new models are really good. The units are very well animated all around. Just stare at some nurglings for a bit if you have doubts. 

-The Gameplay: For the most part, everything is improved (when it functions). Legendary feels a lot more fun to play because the AI has some restraint, they'll still snowball like crazy if you let them but the early game is a lot less brutal. I didn't see the AI bum rushing with 3-4 stacks by turn 20. WHICH IS GOOD cause several factions start off at war with enemies that already have 3-4 settlements/cities.

-The Sounds: All the sound design felt great, from the VA, to the music and in game battle effects. The only sound I didn't like was that the lead belchers sounded a bit too quiet for what is supposed to be a cannon.

-More Dialogue: General speeches are not back properly but your generals will now say a few words at the start of battle and units will talk more in battle and even on the campaign map. One issue I do have is the lack of new dialogue for old factions and the lack of "friendly" dialogue for demons. My vassals still talk down to me in diplomacy screen. 

-The Map Graphics: The maps really good, not much else to say without spoiling them. Though I did think the Khorne maps made things a little hard to see sometimes. 

Ok, now onto sieges that I am still deciding on if they'll bad or good.

-Seiges/Settlements: So siege battle maps are a lot battle and settlements have proper maps now even when not walled. I like the new maps, I like the supplies, but I have a few issues. 
1. I do not like being able to build towers MID BATTLE. It means that destroying them with arty is kinda pointless beacuse in the time it takes to wreck it, they'll get enough supplies for another one. Towers should have to be pre-placed. I am ok with barricades being made mid battle because that's more believable and a lot less annoying. 
2. Some factions are just not good at sieges. Slannesh and Nurgle lack any decent siege equipment. Slannesh get's way too many chariots and calvary in their garrisons. You can overcome with these weaknesses with max tier units, but that is a steep price and long goal.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Player Agency, Strategic Balance
